instructions.MSM Defining Vars 1 (copy 1)_instruction: Write a program that produces a 50 pixel solid green triangle.
instructions.MSM Defining Vars 1_instruction: Write a program that produces a 50 pixel solid green triangle.
instructions.MSM Defining Vars 2 (copy 1)_instruction: If we wanted to make fifty green triangles, it would be a pain to repeat that block of code 50 times. Let's create a variable called "my-shape" and put the code for a 50 pixel solid green triangle inside.
instructions.MSM Defining Vars 2_instruction: If we wanted to make fifty green triangles, it would be a pain to repeat that block of code 50 times. Let's create a variable called my-shape and put the code for a 50 pixel solid green triangle inside.
instructions.MSM Defining Vars 3 (copy 1)_instruction: Take your "my-shape" variable and use it with this provided code to draw two identical green triangles.
instructions.MSM Defining Vars 3_instruction: Take your my-shape variable and use it with this provided code to draw two identical green triangles that are 50 pixels in size.
instructions.MSM Defining Vars 4_instruction: Edit your my-shape variable so that it draws 75 pixel solid red stars.
instructions.MSM Play Lab Butterfly 1_instruction: Help Sam stay on the screen so that you can always see at least a little piece of him. Using the arrow keys, see how far Sam can go to the left while still staying onscreen. Youll find that Sam is onscreen as long as his x-coordinate is greater than -50. Then, fill in the code to make Sam stay on the screen.
instructions.MSM Play Lab Butterfly 2_instruction: Now make Sam stay on the right side of the screen. You'll have to experiment to see how far he can go and still be partially visible on the screen.
instructions.MSM Play Lab Butterfly 3_instruction: Now, combine your work to make Sam stay on both sides of the screen.
instructions.MSM Play Lab Game 2_instruction: Variables can also be used to control the speed of players in a game. Set the player speed and the enemy speed and see how the movement changes. Speed can be between 2 and 12.
instructions.Mike Test Bee Conditionals 1_instruction: This cloud is blocking my view! Check to see if there's a flower under the cloud, and only get nectar if there's a flower. Be careful, it can change!
instructions.Mike Test Bee Conditionals 2_instruction: Collect all of the nectar. You can only collect nectar from flowers, but you can check any space to see if there is a flower.
instructions.MikeTest1_instruction: Who knows what you should do?!?!
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 1_instruct: Can you draw a square that is 100 pixels in length, using a repeat loop?
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 10.1_instr: Use the functions from the previous puzzles to draw this pattern.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 10_instruc: Click "edit" to fill out the blocks in the function definition to make a 40 pixel square.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 11_instruc: Now we want to create a new function called `draw a line of squares` that draws six squares all in a row.  Can you build this function using this `draw a square 20` function that we created for you?
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 12_instruc: Use the `draw a line of squares` function from the last puzzle to draw this pattern.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 13_instruc: Can you draw a star shape using the `draw a line of squares` function?
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 2_instruct: Can you draw 3 squares 20 pixels apart from one another? Each square is 100 pixels in size.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 3_instruct:
Here is a new type of Block. It is called a `function` block. Click "edit" then fill it with the code for drawing a square with 100 pixel sides. 

When you're done editing the function, click "Close" to go back to your program.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 4_instruct: Use the `draw a square` function to draw this pattern.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 5_instruct: How did the "draw a square" block know what commands to run? Click on "edit" in the "draw a square" function block. The blocks in the function editor are the definition that make up "draw a square." When you're done looking around, click "Save and Close" and then "Run."
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 6_instruct: Using the "draw a square" function block, can you draw this picture? Hint: each square is 20 pixels apart.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 7_instruct: Are you getting the hang of how to use function blocks? Let's modify this square so that it is 200 pixels in size. Click on "edit" to enter the `draw a square` function editor. Remember to click on "Close" to get out of the function editor.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 8_instruct: We have created a new function for you called "draw a triangle".  Can you edit the function definition to draw a triangle with 100 pixel sides?
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 9_instruct: Can you solve this by adding only one block?
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions inspire_in: Click here to see the inspiration picture again.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Params 1_instruction: Let's define this function to draw a square with 50 pixel sides. Click "edit" to get started.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Params 10_instructio: Create a `draw a hexagon` function block with a length parameter. This hexagon has sides that are 100 pixels in length.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Params 11_instructio: Can you figure out how to draw this shape? Edit the function to use the "sides" parameter.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Params 12_instructio: Can you complete this drawing? The sides of all the shapes are 100 pixels long.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Params 12a_instructi: This image is similar to the last. Can you use a `for` loop with your function to make this design?
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Params 13_instructio:
Let's edit this "draw a polygon" function. It already has a "sides" parameter. Now, let's add a "length" parameter. 
The perimeter of each shape is 200 pixels long. Do you remember the equation to make shapes the same size when they have a different number of sides?
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Params 14_instructio: Edit "draw a spiral edge" to use "length" and "sides" parameters, then recreate these shapes.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Params 15_instructio: Freeplay: Here are the functions you've written, and some more for you to play with. Draw something awesome! Play with the pen width to see how different your drawings look!
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Params 2_instruction: Create a `draw triangle` function from scratch that makes a triangle with  50 pixel sides.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Params 3_instruction: Now let's use the function to draw 5 triangles in a row. Each triangle is 30 pixels apart.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Params 4_instruction: Do you notice anything different about these function blocks? Click Run to see what happens.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Params 5_instruction: Replace the `???` in the `length` parameter input block. The pentagon has 100 pixel sides.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Params 6_instruction: Fill in the "length" parameter to draw these shapes by replacing the "???" with the right numbers. The square and triangle have 100 pixels sides while each side of the hexagon is 75 pixels long.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Params 7_instruction: Can you complete this drawing? The sides of each triangle are 25 pixels larger than the last.  The first triangle has 25 pixel sides.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Params 8_instruction: The code for this triangle function is broken. Can you edit the function to fix it, and then make triangles of length 25, 50, and 75?
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Params 9_instruction: Click "edit" to fill in the function definition of "draw a square" and add a parameter. It should take a length parameter, just like the triangle. This time, draw 3 squares: 25, 50 and 75 pixels in length, each 100 pixels apart.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Params inspire_instr:
Free Play Inspiration: You've now learned everything you need to know to make a pattern like this! If this picture inspires you, try to make something similar. Otherwise, create something all your own.
 
Want to know how our inspiration pattern was made?
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Vars 1.5_instruction: Take a look at the code, can you see how the "set length" block and "length" block works together? Click on "Run" to see it in action.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Vars 12_instruction: Now, recreate the algorithm from the last level and create a pentagon with sides of length 150.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Vars 2.5_instruction: Take a look at the code, can you see how the "set length" block and "length" block works together? Click on "Run" to see it in action.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Vars 2_instruction: Drag a number block to both the `set length` block and the `repeat _ times` block to draw a set of 50 pixel triangles.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Vars 4 5_instruction: Awesome job on the last puzzle, let's try it again this time let's make this cool design with with 60 pixel hexagon's.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Vars 4_instruction:
Let's try it again! 

Can you set the `length` variable to 60 to make this cool design with hexagons?
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Vars 6_instruction:
Draw this pattern of pentagons with 100 pixel sides by setting the right value for `length` and dropping the `length` variable into all of the the correct places. 

See how you only have to set the value for `length` once, and the code uses the right value everywhere?
instructions.NEW Course 4 Bee For Loops 1_instruction: Use a loop to collect the nectar from each flower.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Bee For Loops 10_instructio: Use your for loop "counter" variable to control how far to move horizontally.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Bee For Loops 10a_instructi: Ready for a challenge?  Take what you've learned about loops and try to solve this problem. Remember: You may have to run through solutions multiple times before you figure out all of the steps.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Bee For Loops 11_instructio: Can you use the loop variable to control movement and nectar collection?
instructions.NEW Course 4 Bee For Loops 2_instruction: Add the code necessary to make sure the bee collects all the nectar. Look at how much code you need for this puzzle! (We'll learn a simpler way in the next puzzle.)
instructions.NEW Course 4 Bee For Loops 3_instruction: Ah, the "for loop" makes this much easier! All the code you need is here, take a look at how it is put together then click "Run" to see how it works.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Bee For Loops 4 4_instructi: Now we need to move forward "counter" times, then get nectar "counter" times.  Can you use two "repeat" loops to solve this challenge?
instructions.NEW Course 4 Bee For Loops 4_instruction: Replace the ??? in the "for loop" with the largest amount of nectar the bee has to collect.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Bee For Loops 5 5_instructi: Are you getting the hang of using the "for loop"? Let's help the bee get the rest of the nectar.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Bee For Loops 5_instruction: You can also use a "for loop" to count down. Try gathering this nectar by counting down from 5 to 1 by 1.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Bee For Loops 6_instruction: The last number in your for loop is called the "increment". Each time the loop is run, the counter variable changes by the value of the increment. Try collecting these flowers using an increment of 2.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Bee For Loops 7_instruction:
Now, let's combine the "counter" variable with a math block! How can you use the "counter" variable to navigate this garden with the fewest number of blocks possible? What do you need to do to collect 3, 6, 9, 12, 15 nectar this time? The secret is in the "counter" variable!

Remember: If your loop is counting up, the increment is added to your "counter" variable each time through.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Bee For Loops 8_instruction: You've got this! What should your increment be to collect 3, 6, 9, 12, 15 nectar?
instructions.NEW Course 4 Bee For Loops 9_instruction: If your loop is counting down, the increment is subtracted from your counter variable each loop. What should your increment be to collect 15, then 12, then 9, 6, 3 nectar?
instructions.NEW Course 4 Bee For Loops 95_instructio: Take a look at each piece of the "for loop" that you have just created.  Can you figure out which numbers you need to double to solve this puzzle? Why does it work?
instructions.NEW Course 4 Play Lab Params 11_instruct: It's free play time! Have fun with all the blocks in your tool box.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Play Lab Params 5 5_instruc: Let's try that again, but with less help. What do you need to edit this time to make the actors patrol?
instructions.NEW Course 4 Play Lab Vars 4 5_instructi: What do you think this code will do? Press Run to see what happens.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Play Labs For Loops 7a_inst: Using what you learned so far, can you have Dinosaur take a step forward every time Penguin counts?
instructions.NEW Course 4 Play Labs For Loops 8 Free: It's Free Play time, have fun with all the blocks in your tool box.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Play Labs For Loops 8a_inst: Challenge: How would you use the "for loop" to get every actor to go around and say their actor number, then vanish from the screen?
instructions.NetSim Standalone Automatic DNS_instruct: In this version of the Internet Simulator, a Domain Name System (DNS) is provided for you and knows the IP addresses of all connected computers. Send a message in the form GET [hostname] to the DNS service at address <yourRouterNumber>.15 to get a student's address.
instructions.NetSim Standalone Broadcast_instruction: In this version of the Internet Simulator, you can connect to up to 5 other people in a room. When you send messages in the room, everyone receives them. What are some of the challenges of this system, and how might you solve them?
instructions.NetSim Standalone Classroom Routers_inst: In this version of the Internet Simulator, everyone connects to a router and has a specific address. To send messages, you have to address your message to the specific address of the recipient, and the router will take care of delivering it to the right computer. If there are other routers created in your class, ask for the address of one of your classmates and send them a message! View the Log Router to see the path the messages have taken through the network.
instructions.NetSim Standalone Freeplay_instruction: In this configuration, most of the options are turned on, and you can play with them. Have fun!
instructions.NetSim Standalone Manual DNS_instruction: In this version of the simulator you can't see the other students' addresses.  Instead, one of you must act as a name service, to help share addresses with each other.
instructions.NetSim Standalone Packets TCP_instructio: Messages on the Internet can take many paths to get to their destination, and sometimes along the way the message gets dropped. In this version of the Internet Simulator, there is a 10% chance of a packet being dropped, multiple packets may take different paths to the destination, and the default max packet size is set to 6 additional characters.
instructions.NetSim Standalone Routers Addresses_inst:
For this activity, connect to a router with the others in your group. Important note: The router will only properly route messages where the first 4 bits are the To: address and the second 4 bits are the From: address.

[TODO: NetSim needs to support hierarchical addresses. For now, level is set up for 4 bit to and from addresses]
instructions.NetSim Standalone SendAB_instruction: You and your partner share a single wire that can only be in state A or state B. You can set the wire to either state at any time, and you can read the state of the wire at any time. Can you figure out a way to effectively communicate with just this system?
instructions.NetSim Standalone Sending Numbers Ascii_: Now that you've transmitted information represented as decimal numbers, you can map those numbers to text characters to send text-based information back and forth. With a text-based protocol, you can easily represent and communicate all kinds of information.
instructions.NetSim Standalone Sending Numbers_instru: You and your partner can now reliably send messages back and forth without extra coordination! While you're always sending bits back and forth, you can also represent those bits as decimal numbers. What kinds of information can you represent with this system?
instructions.NetSim_AddressingMessages_instruction: In this version of the simulator, you will connect to a Router instead of directly to another student. Enter an address in the "To" box to send a message to another student.
instructions.NetSim_AutomaticDNS_instruction: In this version of the simulator a DNS service is provided for you. Send a message in the form GET [hostname] to the DNS service at address 15 to get a student's address.
instructions.NetSim_ManualDNS_instruction: In this version of the simulator you can't see the other students' addresses.  Instead, one of you must act as a name service, to help share addresses with each other.
instructions.NetSim_SendAB_instruction: Connect to another student.  Each of you can set the value of the wire between you to "A" or "B".  See if you can send a complete message!
instructions.NetSim_SendAscii_instruction: In this version of the simulator, you can send numbers or ASCII characters to one another, one bit at a time.
instructions.NetSim_SendBits_instruction: Connect to another student.  You can now set your wire to "0" or "1".  Send a message to your partner!
instructions.NetSim_SendNumbers_instruction: In this version of the simulator, you can view the decimal representations of the binary you are sending.
instructions.NetSim_SendingABTest_instruction: This is Sarah's test of making a netsim level
instructions.NetSim_Superuser_instruction: You have loaded NetSim in superuser mode.
instructions.NetSim_Variant1_instruction: NetSim: Variant 1 allows students to manually work out the timing of sending bits back and forth.
instructions.NetSim_Variant2_instruction: NetSim: Variant 2: Students connect directly to one another and send entire packets back and forth, exploring systems of encoding data.
instructions.NetSim_Variant3_instruction: NetSim: Variant 3: Connects groups of 2-6 students with a router, and explores issues in routing and DNS
instructions.New Artist Project_instruction: Draw something awesome! Your code is saved as a project that you can return to at any time.
instructions.New Basketball Project_instruction: Create your own Basketball game. You can change all the rules. When you're done, click Finish to let friends try your game on their phones.
instructions.New Bounce Project_instruction: Create your own Bounce game. You can change all the visuals and the rules. When you're done, click Finish to let friends try your game on their phones.
instructions.New Course 4 Artist Functions Level 4_in: Use the "draw a square" function to draw this pattern.
instructions.New Gumball Project_instruction: Create anything you like and share it!
instructions.New Ice Age Project_instruction: Create anything you like and share it!
instructions.New Infinity Project_instruction: Create anything you like and share it!
instructions.New Minecraft Hero Project_instruction: **Freeplay:**  Time to explore on your own!
instructions.New Sports Project_instruction: Create your own game! You're in charge here: you can change all the rules, mix and match sports, get creative! When you're done, click Finish to let friends try your game on their phones.
instructions.Ninjacat Demo B (copy 1)_instruction: Lets begin by exploring a simple videogame, and then figuring out how it works. You can use the arrow keys to move the ninja left, right and jump - try to catch the unicorn and avoid the dragon!
instructions.Ninjacat Demo B_instruction: Lets begin by exploring a simple videogame, and then figuring out how it works. You can use the arrow keys to move the ninja up and down - try to catch the unicorn and avoid the dragon! When you think you've figured out how the game works, click "Finish"
instructions.Ninjacat Demo No Animate_instruction: Lets begin by exploring a simple videogame, and then figuring out how it works. You can use the arrow keys to move the ninja up and down - try to catch the unicorn and avoid the dragon! When you think you've figured out how the game works, click "Finish"
instructions.October15 JoL 1_instruction: Program the artist to design a face for your jack-o-lantern!
instructions.October15 bat_instruction: Freeplay: Here are some functions to play with.  Can you draw a bat?
instructions.October15 ghost 1_instruction: Give the ghost eyes, using the "draw a circle" function.
instructions.October15 pumpkin 1_instruction: Finish this jack-o-lantern by drawing the eyes and nose in any style you would like.
instructions.October15 stars 1_instruction: Use loops and the "random integer" block to fill the night sky with stars of different shapes and sizes.
instructions.Overworld Avoid Monsters_instruction: Running into a Creeper is a bad idea. Carefully move past the Creepers and reach the safety of your home.
instructions.Overworld Avoid Monsters_2018_instructio: Running into a Creeper is a bad idea. Carefully move past the Creepers and reach the safety of your home.
instructions.Overworld Chop Tree - allthethings_instr: Wood is a very important resource. Many things are made from it. Walk to the tree and use the destroy block command to chop it down.

instructions.Overworld Free Play 20x20_instruction: Congratulations! You've completed all our puzzles! Now mine, build, and create something unique by using everything you've learned so far.

instructions.Overworld House Frame Chosen_2018_instru: Build the rest of your house from any material you'd like. The "repeat" command will come in handy.
instructions.Overworld Move to Sheep_instruction: Add a second `move forward` block to reach the sheep.
instructions.Overworld Move to Sheep_2018_instruction: Add a second `move forward` block to reach the sheep.
instructions.Overworld Place Wall_instruction: Every house starts with a wall. Build the first part of your house by putting the "place" and "move forward" commands inside the repeat loop.
instructions.Overworld Place Wall_2018_instruction: Every house starts with a wall. Build the first part of your house by putting the "place" and "move forward" commands inside the repeat loop.
instructions.Overworld Plant Crops_instruction: Its good to plan ahead. Plant crops on both sides of the water so you dont get hungry later on.
instructions.Overworld Plant Crops_2018_instruction: Its good to plan ahead. Plant crops on both sides of the water so you dont get hungry later on.
instructions.Overworld Powered Minecart_instruction: Great job! Youve gathered lots of resources and built a modest home. Now lay rail from the edge of the map to the door of your house.
instructions.Overworld Powered Minecart_2018_instruct: Great job! Youve gathered lots of resources and built a modest home. Now lay rail from the edge of the map to the door of your house.
instructions.Overworld Shear Sheep_instruction: Sheep-shearing time! Use the shear command to gather wool from both sheep.
instructions.Overworld Shear Sheep_2018_instruction: Sheep-shearing time! Use the shear command to gather wool from both sheep.
instructions.PDAlg 13-16 Sam Extension Puzzle_instruc: Add a second parameter to "onscreen?" for Sam's y coordinate and update the function so it keeps him safe on all four sides.
instructions.PDAlg 17-20 Luigi Extension Puzzle_instr: Without modifying your existing "cost" function, create a new "coupon" function that takes a pizza topping and coupon code and returns the cost of a pizza with that topping. If the coupon code is correct (you get to decide what it is), apply a 30% discount to the pizza.
instructions.PDAlg 8-12 Rocket Height Puzzle_instruct: Let's write a "rocket-height" function with simple acceleration. Write a function that ensures the rocket is at 15 meters at 1 second, 45 meters at 2 seconds, 95 at 3 seconds, and 165 at 4 seconds.
instructions.PDAlg 8-12 ex dr 1_instruction: The definition in this Design Recipe doesn't match both examples. Test each example to see which is failing, and then fix the definition to match.
instructions.PDAlg 8-12 ex dr 2_instruction: This student has created two examples for the function "apples" but something's not quite right. How would you direct this student to correct their mistake?
instructions.PDAlg Big Game History_instruction: Now that you've played through a Big Game level you should see a new entry in your history. Click the Version History button and you should see at least one version. Each time you go back to a Big Game level you'll get a new record in your version history that you can revert back to.
instructions.PDAlg Big Game Remix_instruction:
Here's your Big Game as you last left it. Try clicking the Remix button to spin off a new remix of your project.

Any changes you make after you click Remix will be saved on your new remix and not on your main Big Game.
instructions.PDAlg Design Recipe Delete_instruction: Click the delete button to get rid of this function, then try creating and deleting a few of your own.
instructions.PDAlg Design Recipe Examples_instruction: The definition in this Design Recipe doesn't match both examples. Test each example to see which is failing, and then fix the definition to match.
instructions.PDAlg Design Recipe Required_instruction: Complete the Design Recipe for the "eggs" function, making sure to create and test your examples.
instructions.PDAlg Updates Cond_instruction: When you went to PD in the summer, the Conditional block that you were introduced to was black and allowed any data type to be used. This proved to be confusing, given that every other function we've seen always produces the same type of data. To help make conditionals clearer and more consistent we've replaced the single black block with a separate block for each data type.
instructions.PDAlg Updates Errors_instruction: Run the provided program and use the error messages to try and track down the bugs.
instructions.PDAlg Updates Space_instruction: Making use of limited programming space (especially on small screens) is challenging with a block based language. To help with this we've added a few features. Experiment with this provided code to see how the space can be manipulated to deal with larger programs.
instructions.PDK5 Conditionals 1_instruction: Purple flowers may have either 1 or 0 nectar, but you don't know which one! Be careful not to collect nectar from a purple flower if it doesn't have any. Check if the nectar is equal to 1 by using the if block.
instructions.PDK5 Conditionals 2_instruction: Try this puzzle that uses conditionals and loops together. Use the "if" block to decide when to turn. Hint: you only need one more block to complete this puzzle.
instructions.PDK5 Events 1_instruction: So far all of the programs we've written are executed in order from top to bottom. In this puzzle, we'll use "Events" to respond to an action on demand. Make the octopus say "Hello" only when you click on the Octopus.
instructions.PDK5 Functions 1_instruction: Hello. Me zombie artist. Me love drawing! Help me draw the square glasses.  Hint:  the bridge between the glasses is 25 pixels shorter than the square length.
instructions.PDK5 Functions 2_instruction: Functions let you define new blocks! We've moved the blocks to draw a square into a function called "draw a square". Can you use the "draw a square" function to create the glasses? The squares are 75 pixels apart.
instructions.PDK5 Loops 1_instruction: Instead of using 5 "move forward" blocks, use the "repeat" block with a "move forward" block inside of it. In computer science, this is called a "loop."
instructions.PDK5 Loops 3_instruction: Here's another puzzle to practice loops. What happens if you use the repeat block to run the code already provided on the workspace 4 times?
instructions.PS - test - pixelation_instruction: Complete the X shape by typing 0s and 1s
instructions.PS FR test 7-25_instruction: Here are your instructions for this free response.
instructions.PS Log test - Define and use turnAround_: Define a function called turnAround. Call the function and then move the turtle forward. (Click to see full instructions)
instructions.PS copy 2-3 Bee Conditionals 5_instructi:
Be careful not to collect nectar from a purple flower if it doesn't have any. 
You must first check if the nectar is equal to 1 using the `if nectar` block.
instructions.Pattern Bee 1_instruction: What a strange field of goodies! I wonder if there's a pattern here...
instructions.Pixelation - AllTheThings 4_instruction: This pixelation level demonstrates the use of the `hide_encoding_controls` option.  Notice that the level displays the image data in hexadecimal and does not let you change it back to binary.
instructions.Pixelation - AllTheThings 5_instruction: This pixelation level demonstrates the use of the "Hide sliders" option.  Notice that the width and height sliders are not available, and the width and height fields are not editable.
instructions.Pixelation - Lesson 14 - Fix bit offset: Something happened to the bits in this image! Find the error and fix it! Hint: a few extra bits were added. You should only need to remove some bits.
instructions.Pixelation - Lesson 14 - Fix bit offset_: A single extra bit was inserted into the stream of bits that make up the C of the Code.org logo. That extra bit bumps all of the other bits down the line which makes the logo look messed up. Hunt down the extra bit and remove it to fix the Code.org logo.

A single extra bit was inserted into the stream of bits that make up the C of the Code.org logo. That extra bit bumps all of the other bits down the line which makes the logo look messed up. Hunt down the extra bit and remove it to fix the Code.org logo.
instructions.Pixelation - Lesson 14 - Fix the error_i: Something happened to the bits in this image!  Find error and fix it!  Hint: a few extra bits were added.  You should only need to remove some bits.
instructions.Pixelation - Lesson 14 - Make the Letter: Make a 3x5 letter 'A'. The widget is setup with the incorrect dimensions. Your first task is to set the second byte to the 8-bit binary code for 5: 0000 0101. Then start entering pixel data.
Make a 3x5 letter 'A'. The widget is setup with the incorrect dimensions. Your first task is to set the second byte to the 8-bit binary code for 5: 0000 0101. Then start entering pixel data.
instructions.Pixelation - Lesson 14 - Make your own B: Now make your own image! We've started you off with a 10x10 canvas but you can make it whatever size you want. Happy pixeling!
Now make your own image! We've started you off with a 10x10 canvas but you can make it whatever size you want.  Happy pixeling!
instructions.Pixelation - Lesson 15 - Color Free Play: Requirements: The icon must be 16x16 pixels. You must use the Pixelation Widget to encode the bits of color information. The image must be encoded with at least 12 bits per pixel.
instructions.Pixelation - Lesson 15 - Color Shades 4x: We start you out with the 4x4 image Maddie created in the video. Your task is to fill a 4x4 grid with colors using 12-bits per pixel. Here are the requirements: Row 1 - fill with shades of red. Row 2 - shades of green. Row 3 - shades of blue. Row 4 - shades of gray.

We start you out with the 4x4 image Maddie created in the video. Your task is to fill a 4x4 grid with colors using 12-bits per pixel. Here are the requirements: Row 1 - fill with shades of red. Row 2 - shades of green. Row 3 - shades of blue. Row 4 - shades of gray.
instructions.Pixelation - Lesson 15 - Color Shades_in: We start you out with the row of shades of red that Maddie created in the video. Experiment with 6-bit color by filling in the bottom row of the image with shades of a different color. Here is an example with some shades of blue. Try your own color!
instructions.Pixelation - Lesson 15 - Color Shades_20: We start you out with the row of shades of red that Maddie created in the video. Experiment with 6-bit color by filling in the bottom row of the image with shades of a different color. Here is an example with some shades of blue. Try your own color!
instructions.Pixelation - Lesson 15 - Complete 3-bit: We start you with the 4x2 image Maddie was creating, but we've left out the last two squares. Finish off the image by figuring out which two colors are missing and encode them.
We start you with the 4x2 image Maddie was creating, but we've left out the last two squares. Finish off the image by figuring out which two colors are missing and encode them.
instructions.Pixelation 2_instruction: Something happened to the bits in this image!  Find error and fix it!
instructions.Pixelation 4x4 Empty_instruction: The width and height are now encoded in the pixel data. Can you figure out how to adjust the dimensions?
instructions.Pixelation Bee_instruction: This larger image of a bee encodes color with 12 bits per pixel, but viewing in hex makes it easier to see the color of each pixel. If you switch to binary mode - hold on to your hat - it's a lot of bits. Here's another mind-blowing thing to try: slide the bits per pixel up to 24 bits per pixel. What happens? Can you explain this behavior?
instructions.Pixelation Bee_2018_instruction: This larger image of a bee encodes color with 12 bits per pixel, but viewing in hex makes it easier to see the color of each pixel. If you switch to binary mode - hold on to your hat - it's a lot of bits. Here's another mind-blowing thing to try: slide the bits per pixel up to 24 bits per pixel. What happens? Can you explain this behavior?
instructions.Pixelation Flappy_instruction: Here is a bigger image at 9 bits per pixel. With 9 bits per pixel you can express 512 different colors. Click through to see the next image which is even more sophisticated, but easier to understand.
instructions.Pixelation Flappy_2018_instruction: Here is a bigger image at 9 bits per pixel. With 9 bits per pixel you can express 512 different colors. Click through to see the next image which is even more sophisticated, but easier to understand.
instructions.Pizza on a Plate_instruction: Project Idea: Create a picture of something familiar from the real world. This requires persistence and planning!

instructions.Play Lab Rocket 1_instruction: A rocket blasts off, traveling at 15 meters per second... press "Run" to see how this word problem looks as an animation.
instructions.Play Lab Rocket 2_instruction: We've started the Design Recipe for rocket-height using the contract and examples you just wrote. Complete the function definition for rocket-height and run your animation.
instructions.Play Lab Rocket 3_instruction: Awesome, now can you update that function so that our rocket moves more quickly? Make sure to update the purpose statement, examples, and function definition to launch a rocket at 40 meters per second.
instructions.Play Lab Rocket 4 (copy 1)_instruction: Real rockets start off slowly and gain speed over time - let's make ours do the same! Write an exponential function that describes a rocket that travels at "seconds" squared meters per second.
instructions.Play Lab Rocket 4_instruction: Real rockets start off slowly and gain speed over time - so let's add some simple acceleration to ours! Can you write a function that describes a rocket that is at 10 meters at 1 second, 40 meters at 2 seconds, 90 meters at 3 seconds, 160 at 4 seconds and so on?
instructions.Play Lab Rocket 5_instruction: Much better, but let's write one more function with simple acceleration. This time the rocket should be 15 meters at 1 second, 45 meters at 2 seconds, 95 at 3 seconds, and 165 at 4 seconds.
instructions.Play Lab Rocket Free Play_instruction: Free Play: Experiment with your rocket-height function to make the rocket fly in different ways. Click "Finish" when you are done.

instructions.Sam the Butterfly 1 (copy 1)_instruction: This butterfly is named Sam, and the game area is Sams yard. Sam's yard is 400 pixels wide by 400 pixels tall! As you can see, Sam is free to walk around the yard, and the coordinates at the top of the screen update to tell you his location. Use the arrow keys to move sam around his yard. Help Sam collect all of the flags to move on.
instructions.Sam the Butterfly 1_instruction: This bat is named Sam, and the game area is Sams yard. Sam's yard is 400 pixels wide by 400 pixels tall! As you can see, Sam is free to walk around the yard, and the coordinates at the top of the screen update to tell you his location. Click "Run" and then use the arrow keys to move Sam around his yard, making note of Sam's coordinates at different locations. Click "Finish" when you're ready to move on.
instructions.Sam the Butterfly 2_instruction: Sam's mom wants to make sure that she can always see at least a bit of him, so lets write some functions that help make sure he doesn't go too far out of the yard. Here's a function called safe-left? - it should take a Number for its domain that represents Sam's x-coordinates and return true if he's completely visible on screen. If your function works, Sam shouldn't be able to leave the yard from the left side.
instructions.Sam the Butterfly 3_instruction: In the last puzzle we kept Sam from leaving on the left, now let's do the same thing on the right. Complete the safe-right? function to make sure Sam can't go off the right side of the screen.
instructions.Sam the Butterfly 4_instruction: Huh, we can keep Sam from leaving on the left, or we can keep him from leaving on the right, but how can we keep him safe from leaving both directions? Try using the and block to program the function on-screen? to check if Sam is safe-left? and safe-right?
instructions.Sam the Butterfly 5_instruction: Free Play: Awesome, we've kept Sam safe on the left and right! Use this free play stage to experiment with your functions and further improve onscreen?
instructions.Sam the Butterfly 6_instruction: We've added a new parameter "y" to the "on-screen?" function. Update the function so that it checks that "safe-left?" AND "safe-right?" AND "safe-up?" are all true. When you've fixed the function, try going out of the yard from the left, right, and top sides.
instructions.Sam the Butterfly 7_instruction: Only one last direction to worry about! Create a "safe-down?" function and update the "on-screen?" function so that it checks up, down, left, and right.
instructions.Sam the Butterfly Complete_instruction: Only one last direction to worry about! Create a "safe-down?" function and update the "on-screen?" function so that it checks up, down, left, and right.
instructions.SpecialFrozenLevel_instruction: You've officially become a master artist! Create a winter wonderland.
instructions.Standalone_Artist_1_instruction: Welcome to Artist! First off, let's try to make a simple square using the turn right block and move forward block. Each side should be 100 pixels long.
instructions.Standalone_Artist_2_instruction: Draw this diamond with 120 and 60 degree angles and 150 pixel long sides.
instructions.Standalone_Artist_3_instruction: Can you draw this hexagon with 100 pixel sides and 60 degree turns?
instructions.Standalone_Artist_4_instruction: Now you've got a new block to play with, the loop. This will repeat a set of commands. What happens if you loop these commands 6 times?
instructions.Standalone_Artist_5.5_instruction: Notice how we simplified the diamond code by turning it into a loop. You can loop that whole sequence 12 times to draw the flower. Hint: You'll need to turn 30 degrees after your diamond loop so you don't keep drawing over the same diamond.
instructions.Standalone_Artist_5_instruction: How many times do you need to loop this diamond to draw the flower?
instructions.Standalone_Artist_6_instruction: Loop this hexagon code 6 times to create the design. How many degrees will you need to turn each time? Hint: divide the number of degrees in a circle by the number of times you are looping.
instructions.Standalone_Artist_7_instruction: A function is another programming tool to help you avoid repeating yourself. This function draws a flower, so you can use it any time you want to draw a flower. Use this and the new jump block to draw these flowers. Hint: The flowers are 150 pixels apart
instructions.Standalone_Artist_8_instruction: Here's a function called "Draw a shape" that we've programmed to draw hexagons. Run the code to see what it does and then experiment with the function to see what happens. Can you make it draw a pattern of squares, triangles, or octagons?
instructions.Standalone_Artist_9_instruction: Now go ahead and make whatever picture you'd like! You've even got an empty function that you can make do whatever you want!
instructions.Standalone_Artist_v2_instruction: Welcome to Artist! First off, let's try to make a simple square using the turn right block and move forward block. Each side should be 100 pixels long.
instructions.StepIntro_instruction: Here's how to use the "Step" button.
instructions.Test Play Lab_instruction: This is a test play lab level.
instructions.Test embedded Blockly in instructions_in:
As a block element, we should be able to include XML representing a valid Blockly block or blocks.

<xml>
  <block type="draw_move_by_constant">
    <title name="DIR">moveForward</title>
    <title name="VALUE">100</title>
  </block>
</xml>

We also support Blockly XML as an inline element like so: <xml><block type="draw_move_by_constant"><title name="DIR">moveForward</title><title name="VALUE">100</title></block></xml>. The difference in input format being that this one is embedded within a paragraph, whereas the previous one is in a text block of its own. The difference in output is comparable.
instructions.Test embedded K1 Blockly in instructions: Use three `move west` blocks and one `pick corn` block to solve this puzzle.
instructions.Test of comment block_instruction: Drag out the subgoal label block you want.
instructions.Testing Quantum Farmer_instruction:
Wow, look at that! 

I don't know how many shovelfuls of dirt this hole needs.  
Can you write a program that keeps using the `fill` block until the ground is even?
instructions.Text Compression 1_instruction: Look for patterns (repeated words or phrases) in the text. Enter the patterns you see into the dictionary on the right. As you type entries into the dictionary, the symbol for the entry is inserted into the text in place of the pattern.
instructions.Total Artist Clone Me_instruction: Freeplay: Here are the functions you've written, and some more for you to play with. Draw something awesome! Play with the pen width to see how different your drawings look!
instructions.U1L10 NetSim numbers with decimal_instru: Invent and test a protocol for encoding and sending text messages. Your protocol must include the letters a-z, spaces, and common punctuation marks. You may add additional characters if you wish. See the worksheet handed out by your teacher for more detailed instructions!
instructions.U1L11 NetSim numbers with Ascii_instruct: Work with a partner or in a small team to develop a protocol that allows you to send formatted text. See the worksheet handed out by your teacher for more detailed instructions!
instructions.U1L13 Text Compression_instruction: Look for patterns (repeated words or phrases) in the text. Enter the patterns you see into the dictionary on the right. As you type entries into the dictionary, the symbol for the entry is inserted into the text in place of the pattern.
instructions.U1L4 NetSim SendAB_instruction: Develop, document, and test a protocol that allows you to use Internet Simulator to relay a message. See the worksheet for more detailed instructions.
instructions.U1L8 NetSim numbers with decimal_instruc: With your partner, develop a protocol or set of rules for communicating a drawing using only bits. See the worksheet handed out by your teacher for more detailed instructions!
instructions.U2L04 - NetSim Routers with Addresses_in: Send messages with your classmates (Click to see full instructions)
instructions.U2L05 - NetSim - Packets and Building TC:
Develop a Protocol for Reliably Sending a Message.

Constraints:
- Packets may contain only 6 characters
- Packets may drop with small probability
- Packets may not arrive in order
instructions.U2L10 NetSim Automatic DNS_instruction: In this version of the Internet Simulator, a Domain Name System (DNS) is provided for you and knows the IP addresses of all connected computers. Send a message in the form GET [hostname] to the DNS service at address <yourRouterNumber>.15 to get a student's address.
instructions.U2L10 NetSim Manual DNS_instruction: In this version of the simulator you can't see the other students' addresses.  Instead, one of you must act as a name service, to help share addresses with each other.
instructions.U2L2 NetSim Hub Mode_instruction: Now use the Internet Simulator to send the battleship moves. For setup, join a Room with your group, and add ships to your paper board for each opponent. When playing, all communication must be done through the tool, so no talking, but have fun!
instructions.U2L3 NetSim Hub Mode_instruction: Use the Internet Simulator to test out your group's binary communication protocol for battleship. How short can you make the message and response?
instructions.U2L4 NetSim Routers Addresses_instructio:
For this activity, connect to a router with the others in your group. Important note: The router will only properly route messages where the first 4 bits are the To: address and the second 4 bits are the From: address.

[TODO: NetSim needs to support hierarchical addresses. For now, level is set up for 4 bit to and from addresses]
instructions.U2L5 NetSim Classroom Internet_instructi: For this activity, connect to a router with the others in your group. The Internet Simulator now provides a place for you to put the To and From addresses, so you don't have to type out the bits manually.
instructions.U2L7 NetSim Need for Packets_instruction: Transfer your favicon to a partner across a network in which the larger a packet grows, the more likely it is to be dropped.

instructions.U3L04 diamond solution_instruction: Study this solution to the drawDiamond problem.  Notice that the whole program starts by calling drawDiamond() at the top.  The program then follows a chain of function calls.  You can trace what's happening in the code to see the functions reused.  It's also easy to read because the function names describe the expected behavior.

See the rubric for more details about requirements and expectations.

instructions.U3L13 - Debug Id plus logic problem_inst:
The last problem was an example of syntax error.  App Lab did not understand which object it should be listening to for a "click" event so it showed an error message in the console to let you know.  Another kind of error is a logical error - the program is valid, but it's not doing what you want it to do.

This program has 2 errors. A (tricky) syntax error and logical error.  Find them, fix them, and make the program work as expected.

instructions.U3L16 - quick double click_instruction: Mini-Project.  The Quick Double-Click game.  In this simple game an object (an image) moves around, or pops up randomly on the screen, as the user clicks it.  The goal of our game will be to try to double-click the object before it moves.  Part of the challenge (and fun) here is creating this app from scratch.  You can look back at your previous work for examples, but it's fun to create something from scratch, too.  Try it!  For more details see the Activity guide for this lesson.

instructions.U3L19 - try out console log_instruction:
Try out console.log.  Do this: replace the statement write("foo is: " + foo) with console.log("foo is: " + foo).  Run the program and you should see the output show up in the console area below the workspace.  Then try adding a few more console.log statements.  Display some text.  Make another variable and display that.  
The app screen will be blank -- that's the point.  With console.log you can test output behind the scenes in a way the user cannot see.  


GIF: U3L19-useconsolelog.gif

instructions.aE1_instruction:
You chose to make a square napkin! 

To finish, draw a square with 20 pixel sides.
instructions.aE2_instruction: If you place your square loop inside another loop, we call that a nested loop. What do you need to add as an outer loop to make sure all 14 napkins line up next to each other?
instructions.aE3_instruction:
We've got to have a tablecloth!  

Take your row of 14 napkins and sew 14 of those together with another **outer loop** to make a cover for our table.
instructions.aE5_instruction: Example of puzzle using highest difficulty level shape.
instructions.aE6_instruction: How many times do you need to loop this to draw half  of a circle?
instructions.aE7_instruction:
If you create another loop like this one, but turn left instead of right, what happens? 

Can you repeat all of that to draw this wave?
instructions.aE8_instruction:
Now let's loop that whole thing four times to create this picture frame. Watch out for the corners - you can't just turn 90 degrees! 

If looping a 3 degree turn 60 times makes a half circle, which of these blocks of code will make an additional quarter circle for the corners?

instructions.behaviors pet test 3_instruction:
**It's time to make your own virtual pet!** You can change whatever code you want to to make your own pet. Here are some ideas:
* Can you make your pet start a new behavior when you click on it?
* Can you make your pet run away when you drag the vacuum to it?
* Can you add other animal friends to your pet's area?
instructions.behaviors pet test_instruction:
Last time, you practiced using "behaviors" to make a sprite do something forever. This time, we will use behaviors to make a virtual pet. 

This dog's name is Daisy. Daisy LOVES to snack on carrots. Add the "drag and drop" behavior to the carrot so you can move it to her.

instructions.bounce_1_instruction: Attach a block to the "when left arrow" block and press "Run". Move the paddle using the left arrow to reach the finish target.
instructions.bounce_10_instruction: There is now a goal at the top. Attach the "score point" and "score opponent point" blocks to the "when ball in goal" and "when ball misses paddle" blocks to make a game. See how many points you can score before your opponent scores twice.
instructions.bounce_10_2018_instruction: There is now a goal at the top. Attach the "score point" and "score opponent point" blocks to the "when ball in goal" and "when ball misses paddle" blocks to make a game. See how many points you can score before your opponent scores twice.
instructions.bounce_10_basketball_instruction: Now there is a goal at the top! Attach the "score point" and "score opponent point" blocks to the "when ball in goal" and "when ball misses hand" blocks to make a game. See how many points you can score before your opponent scores twice.

instructions.bounce_11_instruction: You can now attach blocks to the "when run" block. You have to attach the new "launch new ball" block in more than one place. Also, try changing the scene or the speed of the paddle and the ball and see how many points you can score before your opponent scores twice.
instructions.bounce_11_2018_instruction: You can now attach blocks to the "when run" block. You have to attach the new "launch new ball" block in more than one place. instructions.bounce_11_basketball_instruction: You can now attach blocks to the "when run" block. You have to attach the new "throw new ball" block in more than one place. Also, try changing the scene or the speed of the hand and the ball and see how many points you can score before your opponent scores twice!
instructions.bounce_11_sports_instruction: You can now attach blocks to the "when run" block. You have to attach the new "throw new ball" block in more than one place. Play the game and move Waddles with the arrows until you score enough points.

instructions.courseD_Frozen_nested1_instruction: Draw a small shape, between **20 and 50** pixels wide.  It can be any shape that you like.

instructions.courseD_Frozen_nested6_instruction: Draw a stair-step pattern that uses turns between 75 and 105 degrees.
instructions.courseD_Frozen_nested7_instruction: Now, turn around 180 degrees and draw the stair pattern again!
instructions.courseD_Frozen_nested8_instruction: Spin that shape around 5 or 6 times in a circle.
instructions.courseD_Frozen_nested9_instruction:
Try playing around with what you've created. Draw whatever you like!
- What happens if you use two different angles in your stair step pattern?
- What happens if you make your diamond pattern longer or shorter?
- What does it look like to draw two snowflakes on top of one another?

instructions.courseD_playLab_embedded_instruction:
Move Pegleg the Pirate with the arrow keys. Get to the dragon to score points, but avoid the ninja! Standing below the line of octopuses will make the ninja stop chasing you, but beware! The longer you stay there, the more points you lose. 

Get 5 points to win!

instructions.frozen circle function in circle_instruc: Now let's create 20 overlapping circles, turning 18 degrees between each circle.
instructions.frozen circle function with parameter_in: Here's a Create circle block that can make circles of different sizes. Can you use this to create a small circle of size 5 and a larger circle of size 10?
instructions.frozen circle function_instruction: Use the new Create a circle block to create 10 overlapping circles. Don't forget to jump forward between circles.
instructions.frozen circle_instruction: A circle is a special shape. Can you figure out what number to replace the question marks with to draw a circle?
instructions.frozen cross rotate dense_instruction: Let's repeat it 90 times! How many times does 90 go into 360? Hint: It's a really small number.
instructions.frozen cross rotate_instruction: Now try repeating it 10 times. How many degrees do you need to turn between each line?
instructions.frozen cross_instruction: Wrap a Repeat block around these commands to create a plus sign. Did you notice Elsa can move forward and backward?
instructions.frozen diamond mini snowflake_instructio: Did you know every snowflake is a different shape? Let's create a new snowflake by using another Repeat" block to repeat a parallelogram 4 times, turning right by 90 degrees between each parallelogram.
instructions.frozen diamond snowflake_instruction: Now, let's create a new snowflake by using the repeat block to repeat a parallelogram 10 times, turning right by 36 degrees between each one.
instructions.frozen diamond_instruction: Use a repeat around these blocks to create a parallelogram. It's just like a rectangle but has different angles. This one has 60 degree and 120 degree angles instead of all 90 degree angles.
instructions.frozen freeplay_instruction: You've officially become a master artist! Create a winter wonderland.
instructions.frozen line_instruction: Hi! I'm Elsa of Arendelle. Help me create a single line.
instructions.frozen perpendicular_instruction: Now let's see if we can create two lines that are at a 90 degree angle to each other. You will need to use the "Turn" block as well as the "Move" block.
instructions.frozen snowflake branch_instruction: Try using the Create a snowflake branch block to create three branches, which starts to look like a snowflake.
instructions.frozen snowflake full_instruction: Now let's repeat it 8 times to make a beautiful snowflake!
instructions.frozen snowflower_instruction: Intricate snow patterns can be created with very simple shapes. Can you make a pattern by repeating 5 circles of size 5 and 5 circles of size 10?
instructions.frozen square iterative_instruction: It seems like we're halfway to making a square. Let's put 4 lines together to create a square.
instructions.frozen square loop 3x_instruction: Let's create three squares, turning after each square. Be sure to turn by 120 degrees before each new square.
instructions.frozen square loop_instruction: Hi, Im Anna of Arendelle! Lets make a square with the Repeat block, which uses fewer blocks. How many times (???) should the Repeat block loop the blocks inside it to make a square?
instructions.frozen square snowflake_instruction: Can you create a snowflake using the Repeat block to make a square 10 times, and the Turn block to turn 36 degrees between each square?

instructions.grade1_artist_loops4_instruction: Time to fix the stairs!  Repeat this pattern five times so the artist can reach the top of the bushes.
instructions.grade1_artist_loops5_instruction: Behind the bushes there is a beautiful vine full of flowers.  Can you climb the vine and see where it goes?
instructions.grade1_artist_loops6_instruction: **Challenge:**  It's a hidden garden! Let's walk around.
instructions.grade1_artist_loops7_instruction: The flowers down here are so pretty.  Let's take a closer look.
instructions.grade1_artist_loops7a_instruction: **Challenge:**  Lovely! Let's take a walk around the garden.
instructions.grade1_artist_loops7b_instruction: Time to head home. Can you fix this ladder to help the artist get down?
instructions.grade1_artist_loops8_instruction: Let's take the short way home, over the pond. Can you help the artist stay on the stones?
instructions.grade1_artist_loops9_instruction: I still need a story for this puzzle
instructions.grade1_artist_loopsFP_instruction: Use what you have learned to draw a picture of what you think the artist saw when he got home.
instructions.grade1_maze_sequence1_instruction: A bug! Fix the code to get me to the pig.
instructions.grade1_maze_sequence10_instruction: Move me around the TNT to get to the pig.
instructions.grade1_maze_sequence2_instruction: Fix the code to get me to the pig!
instructions.grade1_maze_sequence3_instruction: Add 2 blocks to get the bird to the pig.
instructions.grade1_maze_sequence4_instruction: Now try this puzzle from the start!
instructions.grade1_maze_sequence5_instruction: Move one way, then another to get me to the pig!
instructions.grade1_maze_sequence6_instruction: Figure out what is missing and then add blocks to get me to the pig!
instructions.grade1_maze_sequence7_instruction: Your turn!  What do you need to do to get the bird to the pig?
instructions.grade1_maze_sequence8_instruction: Debug this level by adding blocks to get me to the pig!
instructions.grade1_maze_sequence9_instruction: Go around the TNT to get me to the pig!
instructions.grade1_maze_sequenceA_instruction: Challenge: Move me around the TNT to get to the pig.
instructions.grade1_maze_sequenceB_instruction: Fix the bugs to get the bird to the pig.
instructions.grade1_maze_sequenceC_instruction: It's all you!  Get the bird to the pig.
instructions.grade1_maze_sequenceD_instruction: Now head any which way to get that pig!
instructions.grade1_playlab_events1_instruction: This game is called "Play Lab".  See if you can figure out what each block does.
instructions.grade1_playlab_events1a_instruction: Make your robot say "Hello!" when the button is clicked.
instructions.grade1_playlab_events2_instruction: This program makes Robin fly.  Can you get her to vanish when you click her?
instructions.grade1_playlab_events2a_instruction: Edit the code so that when the second bird is clicked, your program plays a sound!
instructions.grade1_playlab_events3_instruction: This program makes Robin fly.  Can you make the robot jump when you press the up button?
instructions.grade1_playlab_events3a_instruction: When the third bird is clicked, the background should change to a city. Can you add code to make this happen?
instructions.grade1_playlab_events4_instruction: Add a block to make Robin vanish when she collides with the robot.
instructions.grade1_playlab_events4a_instruction: Add code to make something happen when the fourth bird is clicked. Be creative!
instructions.grade1_playlab_events5_instruction: Add a block to the 'when run' event that starts the dragon flying.
instructions.grade1_playlab_events5a_instruction: About My Robot Project! Write code so that clicking on each bird shows a new fact about your robot.
instructions.grade1_playlab_events6_instruction: Add a block to the 'when actor 1 clicked' event that makes the dragon return to the middle of the screen.
instructions.grade1_playlab_events7_instruction: Add a block so that when you push the left arrow button, the knight surges toward the dragon.
instructions.grade1_playlab_events8_instruction: Add a block so that when the knight collides with the dragon, it plays a sound.
instructions.grade1_playlab_events9 RYAN COPY_instruc: Now, have Robin wait a second, then come back after she vanishes.
instructions.grade1_playlab_events9_instruction: Now, add a block to keep score each time the knight hits the dragon.
instructions.grade1_playlab_eventsFP_instruction: Use your imagination. What can you do to make this game more fun?
instructions.grade1_sequence_pre_instruction: Play with these blocks to see what they make the bird do!
instructions.grade1_video_frustrationRainbow_instruct: This video describes the rainbow of frustration and introduces persistence.
instructions.grade2_CaringForNewPet_0_instruction: For this puzzle, drag all of the blocks together and click "Run" to watch it go!
instructions.grade2_CaringForNewPet_1_instruction: Drag an extra `move forward` block out of the toolbox to finish your code.
instructions.grade2_CaringForNewPet_11_instruction: "Keep calm and help me find the bad pig."
instructions.grade2_CaringForNewPet_2_instruction:
"This pig is ruffling my feathers."

There is one extra block that is going to cause the bird to crash. Throw it away by dragging it back to the toolbox.
instructions.grade2_CaringForNewPet_2courseC_maze_pro: There is one extra block that is going to cause the bird to crash. Throw it away by dragging it back to the toolbox.
instructions.grade2_CaringForNewPet_3_instruction: "Trace the path and lead me to the silly pig. Avoid TNT or feathers will fly!"
instructions.grade2_CaringForNewPet_3D_instruction: "Follow this path to get me to the pig!"
instructions.grade2_CaringForNewPet_4_instruction: "Keep calm and help me find the bad pig. Otherwise I might get angry!"
instructions.grade2_CaringForNewPet_6_instruction: Challenge: Guide me to the green evilness! (Watch out for TNT)
instructions.grade2_CaringForNewPet_7D_instruction: Challenge: This code has a lot of bugs. You'll need to remove blocks and add blocks.
instructions.grade2_MakeDogTag_1_instruction: Drag blocks onto the screen to have the artist draw over the grey lines in the picture. (Each line is 100 pixels long)
instructions.grade2_MakeDogTag_2_instruction:
This spaceship needs a window!

Each side of the inner square is 100 pixels and all of the angles are 90 degrees.
instructions.grade2_MakeDogTag_3_instruction:
"Oh no!  Starla's pet alien just flew away! Let's help the spacewoman!"

Finish Starla's rocket so she can chase her pet.
instructions.grade2_MakeDogTag_4_instruction:
Finish this tag by drawing a rectangle around the outside.
(The long sides are 200 pixels each and the short sides are each 100 pixels)
instructions.grade2_MakeDogTag_5_instruction:
"Now a tag for Belle!"

Draw this diamond with 200 pixel sides.
instructions.grade2_MakeDogTag_6_instruction: Challenge: This tag is a special one!  Can you figure out how to draw the outline?
instructions.grade2_MakeDogTag_7_instruction:
One more tag.  This is a triangle for Pi.
(Each side is 150 pixels)
instructions.grade2_MakeDogTag_8_instruction: Now let's connect a bunch of V's together in a loop.
instructions.grade2_MakeDogTag_9_instruction: Rebuild the code from the last puzzle, but this time, add a left turn of 30 degrees inside the loop. Now, repeat it 24 times instead of 8.
instructions.grade2_MakeDogTag_BFP_instruction:
"Hi, I'm an artist. You can write code to make me draw almost anything."

Play with the blocks in the toolbox to see what they do!
instructions.grade2_MakeDogTag_FP_instruction: Freeplay: What shape will you make the tag for your pet?
instructions.grade2_PuppyLoops_1_instruction: Can you get me to the pig using 5 of the same kind of blocks?
instructions.grade2_PuppyLoops_10_instruction:
My teacher says that I should finish what I start!

Help me finish my pinwheel. Can you figure out what's wrong?
instructions.grade2_PuppyLoops_2_instruction: Can you get to the pig by creating a loop that uses only one `move forward` block inside of a `repeat`?
instructions.grade2_PuppyLoops_3_instruction: Get me to the pig! Solve this puzzle by creating a loop!
instructions.grade2_PuppyLoops_4_instruction: In this puzzle, two `repeat` loops will help you get to the pig with the fewest number of blocks!
instructions.grade2_PuppyLoops_5_instruction: Can you figure out the fastest way to get me to the pig?
instructions.grade2_PuppyLoops_6_instruction: Loops even work with more than one block inside!  Can you loop this sequence to get me to the pig?
instructions.grade2_PuppyLoops_7_instruction: Use what you learned to get me to the sunflower!
instructions.grade2_PuppyLoops_8_instruction:
This code for the cat's whiskers is wrong. 

Fix this code to draw whiskers that are all the same length.
instructions.grade2_PuppyLoops_9_instruction:
Looks like the C in code is drawn backwards!

Can you make it look like a C again?
instructions.grade2_collector_10_instruction: You're almost done! Collect as many pieces of treasure as you can to finish the stage!
instructions.grade2_collector_10_2018_instruction: You're almost done! Collect as many pieces of treasure as you can to finish the stage!
instructions.grade2_collector_2_instruction: Move Laurel to the gold, then use `collect` to pick it up.
instructions.grade2_collector_3_instruction: Put these blocks in order to collect all of the gold and solve the puzzle.
instructions.grade2_collector_4_instruction: Sequence matters! The blocks you need are already in the workspace, but not connected.  Order these blocks to solve the puzzle.
instructions.grade2_collector_5_instruction: These blocks are in the wrong order. Can you fix them?
instructions.grade2_collector_6_instruction: Reorder the blocks to collect all of the treasure.
instructions.grade2_collector_7_instruction: Challenge puzzle! Use blocks from the toolbox to collect all of the treasure.
instructions.grade2_collector_8_instruction: "Keep up the good work! Help me collect all of the coins."
instructions.grade2_collector_A_instruction: Help Laurel collect all of the treasure.
instructions.grade2_collector_A_2018_instruction: Help Laurel collect all of the treasure.
instructions.grade2_collector_pre1_instruction:
"Hi, I'm Laurel. Today I'm searching for treasure at the dog park!" 

Play around with the blocks to see if you can help Laurel collect some gold.
instructions.grade2_maze_debuggingFP_instruction: "Now, help me sneak up on the pig any way you want to!"
instructions.grade2_maze_debuggingPre_instruction: Play with these blocks to see what they make the bird do!
instructions.grade2_maze_intro2_instruction: Welcome to Code Studio! Here you will learn to use blocks to build programs. Press `Run` to run a program now!
instructions.grade2_maze_intro3_instruction: The `workspace` is where you will create all of your programs. Can you guess what this program does? Press the Run button to find out.
instructions.grade2_maze_intro4_instruction: Drag a block from the toolbox into the workspace. Connect it to the other blocks.
instructions.grade2_maze_intro6_instruction: Thats it!  Now were ready to try to solve a few puzzles.
instructions.grade2_maze_intro7_instruction: This time, try something a bit more challenging.
instructions.grade2_maze_intro8_instruction: This is a challenge puzzle.  It is meant to be hard and will probably take you a couple of tries to solve.  If you dont solve it after several tries, dont worry!  It will be in the Play Zone at the end of the stage and you can try it again when youve had more practice.
instructions.grade2_playlab_project_1_instruction: Now, write a program to make Waddles move around using the up / down / left /right keys to hit all of the targets!
instructions.grade2_playlab_project_2_instruction: The `repeat forever` block allows you to run code over and over forever. Can you attach blocks to move Chomp the Dino (actor 2) up and down forever?
instructions.grade2_playlab_project_3_instruction:
Can you have Waddles (actor 1) say "Ouch!" and play a "hit" sound if he runs into Chomp? 

When you're done, play the game to make that happen.
instructions.grade2_playlab_project_4_instruction:
Can you add a block to score a point when Waddles runs into Octavia (actor 3)? 
Play the game and move Waddles with the arrows until you score!
instructions.grade2_playlab_project_5_instruction:
Add blocks to the `when run` event to change the background and the speed of Waddles.

Play the game and move Waddles with the arrows until you score.
instructions.grade2_playlab_project_6_instruction: Create your own story. When you're done, click "Finish" to share with friends.
instructions.grade2_puppy_loops2_instruction: Can you get to the pig by creating a loop that uses only one `move forward` block inside of a `repeat`?
instructions.grade2_puppy_loops3_instruction:
"Get me to the pig!"

 Solve this puzzle by creating a loop!
instructions.grade2_puppy_loops4_instruction: In this puzzle, two `repeat` loops will help you get to the pig with the fewest number of blocks!
instructions.grade2_puppy_loops5_instruction: "Get me to the pig as quickly as possible!"
instructions.grade2_puppy_loops6_instruction:
"This pig is ruffling my feathers!"
