This puzzle is making me loopy! 

Fix the error(s) to collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Debugging 2_markdown_instruction:
Can you find the problem here?

Fix the error(s) to collect all of the nectar.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Debugging 3_markdown_instruction:
Ooh, this one stings!

Fix the error(s) to collect all of the nectar.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Debugging 5_markdown_instruction:
That flower looks tasty! 

Fix the error(s) to collect all of the nectar.

markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Debugging 6_markdown_instruction:
What a sweet challenge!

Fix the error(s) to collect all of the nectar.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Debugging 9_markdown_instruction:
"Bee" patient with this one!

You will need to fix a couple of things in this program to collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey.

**Assessment:**  Now it's time to show what you know!

markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Functions 1_markdown_instruction:
Functions are blocks of code that perform a task.  

Use the `get 2 nectar` function to collect the nectar from each flower.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Functions 10_markdown_instructio:
Purple flowers change between either 1 or 0 nectar each time you run the puzzle.   

Create a function that collects nectar only from purple flowers that have nectar.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Functions 2_markdown_instruction:
Functions are blocks of code that perform a task.  

Use the `get 5` function to get 5 nectars at a time.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Functions 4_markdown_instruction:
The `move and get nectar` function turns the bee, collects nectar, and then returns the bee to where it started.  

Use the function to collect all of the nectar.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Functions Assessment 1_markdown_: **Assessment:** Use the given function to collect nectar from each flower.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Functions Assessment 2_markdown_: **Assessment:** Create a function to turn, move forward and make 3 honey, then return the bee to where it started and turn back.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Loops 1_markdown_instruction:
Those flowers look tasty!

Collect nectar from each of the flowers using the fewest blocks possible.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Loops 13_markdown_instruction: **Assessment:** Collect all of the nectar using the fewest blocks possible.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Loops 3A_markdown_instruction: Use a `repeat` loop to collect all of the nectar.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Loops 3B_markdown_instruction: Now use the `repeat` block to collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Loops 4_markdown_instruction:
Such a busy bee!

Help Bee collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey with the fewest blocks possible.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Loops 4A_markdown_instruction:
How many times can loops help you in this puzzle?  

Loops are your friend! Use a few of them to complete this puzzle with the fewest blocks possible.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Loops 5_markdown_instruction:
The shape of this path is different from the others. 

Can you collect all of the nectar using as few blocks as possible?
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Loops 7_markdown_instruction:
What a beautiful field of flowers!   

Help the bee visit each one.

Can you find a way to do it with fewer than 7 blocks?
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Loops 8_markdown_instruction:
These purple flowers have different amount of nectar each time you run the puzzle. 

Use the `while nectar` loop to collect all of the nectar. 

This loop will run as long as the condition is true, in this case `nectar > 0`.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Loops Assessment 1_markdown_inst: **Assessment:** Use a `while` loop to collect all of the nectar from these flowers.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Maze 1_markdown_instruction:
Can you help me catch the naughty pig? 

Stack a couple of `move forward` blocks below the `when run` block and press "Run".
markdown_instructions.2-3 Maze 12 - One Move Block_markdown_in:
Get the mean pig! But this time, you can only use one `move forward` block...

Ah, look closely - do you see any other blocks that can help you get there?
markdown_instructions.2-3 Maze 12_markdown_instruction:
Suddenly, a magical block appears!  With the `repeat` block, you can loop code over and over.

Can you get to the pig by creating a loop that uses only one `move forward` block inside of a `repeat`?
markdown_instructions.2-3 Maze 13_markdown_instruction: Get me to the pig! You can only use one `move forward` block this time
markdown_instructions.2-3 Maze 15_markdown_instruction: In this puzzle, two `repeat` loops will help you get to the pig with the fewest number of blocks!
markdown_instructions.2-3 Maze Loops 18_markdown_instruction:
Get me to the sunflower using the fewest blocks possible!  

Try using one `repeat` loop inside of another to cut down on the amount of code you need.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Maze Loops 19_markdown_instruction:
Let's take this to another level! 

Use loops to get me to the sunflower with the fewest loops possible.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Maze Loops Assessment 1_markdown_ins: **Assessment:**  Get me to the sunflower using only 5 blocks!

Next, repeat the code enough times to complete the drawing!

This rectangular flower bed has a perimeter of 600.

markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 1_markdown_instructi:
Draw this square using a loop.

Each side is 20 pixels long.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 10_markdown_instruct:
This code draws two rows of hexagons - loop the whole thing 4 times to draw the whole honeycomb. 

You'll need to jump back 120 pixels in your outermost loop to make sure the artist doesn't draw off the screen.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 11_markdown_instruct: How many times do you need to loop this to draw a half circle?
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 12_markdown_instruct:
If you create another loop like this one, but turn left instead of right, what happens? 

Can you repeat all of that to draw this wave?
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 13_markdown_instruct:
Now let's loop that whole thing four times to create this picture frame. Watch out for the corners - you can't just turn 90 degrees! 

If looping a 3 degree turn 60 times makes a half circle, which of these blocks of code will make an additional quarter circle for the corners?
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 2_markdown_instructi:
If you place your square loop inside another loop, we call that a nested loop. 

What do you need to add as an outer loop to make sure all 15 squares line up next to each other?
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 3_markdown_instructi: Now let's go one level deeper! We've nested that whole block of code into another loop, but you need to get the artist back in place to draw the next line. Which of these code blocks can you place at the end of the outermost loop to draw the whole grid?
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 4_markdown_instructi:
This diamond has 50 pixel sides and angles of 120 and 60 degrees. 

Use a loop to draw it.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 5_markdown_instructi:
Repeat this code to make a row of 6 diamonds. 

Notice that we changed our diamond code to repeat 3 times instead of 2 - why do you think that is?
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 6_markdown_instructi: How many times do you need to repeat this block to draw the full grid of diamonds?
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 7_markdown_instructi: Let's modify the code from the last puzzle to make this more complex pattern. Notice how the diamonds overlap now, try changing the first "jump backwards" from 100 to 50 (half as far) - now how far should the artist go in the second "jump backwards"?
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 8_markdown_instructi: Use a loop to draw this hexagon with 40 pixel sides and 60 degree angles.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 9.5_markdown_instruc:
Let's loop this code to draw two rows of hexagons. 

Notice how our second row is shifted to the right.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 9_markdown_instructi:
Now repeat this code 3 times and draw the whole row. 

Each hexagon is 80 pixels wide from the furthest points left to right.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns Free Play_markdown_i: Free play - try your hand at making a pattern of your own!
markdown_instructions.4-5 Bee Conditionals 1_markdown_instruct:
This cloud is blocking my view! 

Check to see if there's a flower under the cloud, and only get nectar if there's a flower.   
Be careful, it can change!
markdown_instructions.4-5 Bee Conditionals 2_markdown_instruct:
More clouds! 

Check underneath every cloud to see if it is hiding a flower before you get nectar.  

Remember: Not all clouds hide the same thing!
markdown_instructions.4-5 Bee Conditionals 4_markdown_instruct:
Sometimes this cloud covers a flower, and sometimes it covers a honeycomb! 

Use the `if/else` block to collect nectar only if it is a flower.  
Else, make honey (because it is a honeycomb).
markdown_instructions.4-5 Bee Conditionals 5_markdown_instruct:
There will be either a flower or a honeycomb under each of those clouds!

Use the `if/else` block to collect nectar if there is a flower.
Otherwise, make honey (because there is a honeycomb).
markdown_instructions.4-5 Bee Conditionals 6_markdown_instruct:
I am not sure how much nectar this flower has, but I know it has either 1, 2, or 3 nectar. 

Combine the conditional blocks (`if` and/or `if/else`) to only get as much nectar as the flower has. 

Remember, the amount of nectar can change each time you run the puzzle!
markdown_instructions.4-5 Bee Conditionals 7_markdown_instruct:
These flowers can have 3, 2, or 1 nectar. 

Complete the `check purple flower` function and use it to collect all of the nectar at the flowers.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Bee Conditionals 8_markdown_instruct:
Write the function for `check flower make honey`. 

Your function should check if the purple flower has 3, 2, or 1 nectar and get all of the nectar. 
Then, move forward and make honey.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Bee Conditionals Assessment 1_markdo:
**Assessment:** This cloud is either hiding a flower with one nectar or a honeycomb that needs one honey.  

Complete the `get nectar or make honey` function, then call it to collect the nectar or honey.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Bee Debugging 1_markdown_instruction:
These blocks are really bugging me. 

Can you fix them?
markdown_instructions.4-5 Bee Debugging 6_markdown_instruction:
The purple flower has a different amount of nectar each time you run the puzzle. 

Fix the blocks to get all of the nectar from the flower each time.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Bee Nested Loops 2_markdown_instruct:
Collect all of the nectar from each flower. 

Use a nested loop.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Bee Nested Loops 4_markdown_instruct:
Collect all of the nectar from each flower and make honey at the honeycomb. 

Use a nested loop.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Bee Nested Loops Assessment 1_markdo: **Assessment:** Collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey using loops.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Maze 7_markdown_instruction:
Get the zombie to the sunflower quickly!  

Can you solve the puzzle in fewer than 11 blocks?
markdown_instructions.4-5 Maze 9_markdown_instruction:
Now we have a new block called `repeat until`.  
This will let us keep looping commands until the zombie gets the sunflower.  

Use the new `repeat until` block to solve this puzzle in as few commands as possible.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Maze Assessment 1_markdown_instructi: **Assessment:** Get to the sunflower using as few blocks as possible.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Maze Conditionals 1_markdown_instruc: Use the `repeat until` block to get the zombie to the sunflower.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Maze Conditionals 10_markdown_instru:
Can you add just 3 blocks to help the zombie solve a more complex maze? 

If you do it right, he can walk any curvy path no matter the length!
markdown_instructions.4-5 Maze Conditionals 2_markdown_instruc: Use the `repeat until` block to get the zombie to the sunflower.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Maze Conditionals 3_markdown_instruc: Use the `if` block to help me decide when to turn.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Maze Conditionals 4_markdown_instruc: Ok, solve this one just like the last puzzle, but you need to remember how you used the `if` and `repeat until` blocks together.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Maze Conditionals 5_markdown_instruc:
"Me want sunflower!"  

Use an `if` statement to get the zombie to the sunflower with the fewest number of blocks.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Maze Conditionals 6_markdown_instruc:
"Eat sunflower!"

Use an `if` statement to get the zombie to the sunflower with the fewest number of blocks.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Maze Conditionals 7_markdown_instruc: The solution to this puzzle isn't very different, but watch out for the chompers!
markdown_instructions.4-5 Maze Conditionals 8_markdown_instruc:
The `if/else` block checks a condition, and then does one thing OR another. 

Use this new block to get me to the sunflower.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Maze Conditionals 9_markdown_instruc:
One more practice puzzle with the `if/else` block!

Trace it with your finger to see if you can figure it out on your first try.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Maze Conditionals Assessment 1_markd: **Assessment:** Use a `repeat until` and an `if/else` block to get me to the sunflower in as few blocks as possible.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Nested Loops 1_markdown_instruction: Complete the code to draw these triangles.  The first one is done for you.  Hint:  3 triangles in a 360 degree rotation.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Nested Loops 11_markdown_instruction:
Can you draw these 10 squares of this sidewalk using a nested loop? 

Each square is 30 pixels.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Nested Loops 12_markdown_instruction: Can you draw these 36 triangles using a nested loop?
markdown_instructions.4-5 Nested Loops 2_markdown_instruction:
Now nest this loop inside another loop to draw 10 triangles.  
This is called a "nested" loop.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Nested Loops 3_markdown_instruction:
Create a sun by nesting the starter code in another loop.

To get this cool design with a hollow center, you'll need to jump forward by the length of the triangle before turning.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Nested Loops 5_markdown_instruction: Loop the given code to create a windmill.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Nested Loops 6_markdown_instruction: Can you draw a hexagon by looping the triangle code?
markdown_instructions.4-5 Nested Loops 7_markdown_instruction:
Loop this design 10 times. 

How much do you have to turn each time you loop?
markdown_instructions.4-5 Nested Loops 8_markdown_instruction:
Loop this shape 6 times. 

How much do you have to turn each time you loop?
markdown_instructions.4-5 Nested Loops 9_markdown_instruction: Draw the teeth in the alligator's mouth!
markdown_instructions.4-5 Nested Loops Assessment 1_markdown_i: **Assessment:** Use a nested loop to complete the design.
markdown_instructions.4-5 While Loops 1_markdown_instruction: Move me to the hole and fill it with two shovelfuls of dirt, using the `fill` block.
markdown_instructions.4-5 While Loops 2_markdown_instruction: Move me to the pile of dirt and remove it with 5 shovel scoops, using the `remove 1` block.
markdown_instructions.4-5 While Loops 3_markdown_instruction:
Use as few blocks as possible to complete this puzzle!  

Move me to the pile and remove all the dirt, then move to the hole and fill it completely.
markdown_instructions.4-5 While Loops 4_markdown_instruction:
Wow, look at that! 

I don't know how many shovelfuls of dirt this hole needs.

markdown_instructions.Alien Defender_2018_markdown_instruction: **Project Idea**: Make a defender game in Play Lab!
markdown_instructions.AppLab Intro 2 - Edit place1_markdown_in:
On the last screen you gave your character a choice between to actions or places. Pick one of them and start making a screen for it!

1. In the screen selector choose "New screen..." ([Show me where](#triggercallout=selector))
2. Change the "id" of the screen to something clear, for example the name of the new location ([Show me where](#triggercallout=idChange))
3. You can switch back and forth between your two screens from the screen selector. ([Show me where](#triggercallout=selector))
4. You can select the "background-color" of your screen if you like.

Click "Run" and then "Finish" to move on and start adding to your screen.
markdown_instructions.AppLab Intro 2 - Edit startScreen2_markd:
Nice work! Time to start filling in your story.

1. Click the story text on this screen. ([Show me where](#triggercallout=storyText))
2. Fill in your story ([Show me where](#triggercallout=editStoryText))
3. Explore the different properties you can change in the menu. Personalize this screen's look! ([Show me where](#triggercallout=changeTextColor))

Hit "Run" once to make everything looks good. Then hit "Finish" to move on!
markdown_instructions.AppLab Intro 2 - Try Cat Commander_markd:
This is what the code for Cat Commander looks like. Take one minute to scroll through the code and see if you can understand how it works. Talk about it with a partner. What patterns do you see? 

Once you're done, move on by clicking "Run" then "Finish", to learn to build your own adventure.
markdown_instructions.AppLab Intro 2 - add sound_markdown_inst: You can add sound to your app too! Add them outside an `onEvent()` to play from the start of the adventure (good for background music) or inside an `onEvent()` to play when that button is clicked (good for "Win" / "Lose" sounds). 1. Drag a `playSound()` block into your program 2. Click the dropdown, then "Choose...", then "Sound Library" to find the library of sounds built into App Lab 3. Try out the "Background" category for longer songs that will play for your entire adventure. 4. Hit "Choose" to select the sound you like. 5. You can also drag code inside an `onEvent` block to play sound only when an event happens. Shorter sounds work better here. Run your app. There should be sound playing now too!
markdown_instructions.AppLab Intro 2 - finish and share_markdo:
Congrats on finishing your Hour of Code! You can share your work with friends! Click "Share" to get a link or even text it to them.

You can keep working on your project here. Whenever your friends go to the link you shared they'll get the latest version you made. How far will you build your adventure?
markdown_instructions.AppLab Intro 4 - thisOrThat design_markd:
**Goal:** Try out Design Mode to keep making changes to your This or That App. There's also some new blocks in your toolbox! You'll learn more about these in later lessons.

**How:** Click into "Design" to quickly edit how your app looks or add screen elements yourself. Experiment with some of the new blocks in the toolbox.
markdown_instructions.AppLab Intro 4 - thisOrThat template_mar:
**Goal:** Try out Design Mode to keep making changes to your This or That App. You'll learn more in later lessons.

**How:** Click into "Design" to quickly edit how your app looks or add screen elements yourself.
markdown_instructions.AppLab Intro 5 - go further_markdown_ins: **Goal:** This is a blank App Lab project. Build whatever you like here! You also have a few more blocks you can try out if you like. Don't forget to share your work!
markdown_instructions.AppLab Intro 5 - share keep going_markdo:
**Goal:** Share your app with someone, or just send it to yourself! Then keep building it out!

**How:** Click "Share" to find lots of ways to share your app. Here's some ideas to try

* Add a button that takes you back from `"screen2"` to `"screen1"`
* Add more screens with more images
* Add more types of reaction buttons that users can click
markdown_instructions.AppLab Intro 5 - socialTemplate_markdown:
**Goal:** Add a button to the screen for scrolling to the next image. Give it a good icon, like a right arrow. In the next level you'll make it work.

**How:** Use Design Mode to drag in a button. The icon library has many different arrows to choose from. Don't forget you can search for them.

**Show Me:**
markdown_instructions.AppLab Intro 6 - animalSoundBoard_markdo:
**Goal:** Keep building out the Animal Sound board. Then make sure to "Share" it.

**How:** Add new buttons for more animals. Or make the soundboard for a totally different topic entirely!
markdown_instructions.AppLab Intro 6 - blankApp_markdown_instr:
**Goal:** This is a completely blank App Lab App. Build whatever you want from scratch!?

**How:** You're in control here. You decide what you want to make!
markdown_instructions.AppLab Intro 6 - quizApp_markdown_instru:
**Goal:** Build out three questions in this Quiz App. You can always make more questions by duplicating screens. Then send it to a friend!

**How:** Run the app first and try clicked all the buttons to see how it works. Then from Design Mode you can change the default text for the questions and buttons. In Code mode create response text for when the user clicks the different buttons. Customize the colors or add images if you want too!
markdown_instructions.AppLab Intro 6 - thisOrThatAddButton Tem:
**Goal:** Add a second button to the screen that says "Right!"

**How:** In Design Mode drag in a new button. Position and resize it. Then set its `"text"`, `"background color"`, and `"font size"`

**Show Me:**
markdown_instructions.AppLab Intro 6 - thisOrThatPersonalize_m:
**Goal:** Start building your own "Choose Your Own Adventure" app. Don't forget to "Share" it with someone! **How:** Choose the basic story you want to tell, like who your character is and the setting. Then change the text and images of your app to match the story. You can always add more screens as you keep building out your adventure.
Stuck? Click here for some ideas
  • Make an adventure about your favorite fictional character
  • Make an adventure about a famous (or not-so-famous person) you're a big fan of
  • Make an adventure that has a lot of unexpected twists or has a difficult moral choice

markdown_instructions.Artist Inspiration_markdown_instruction: **Free-Play Inspiration:** You've now learned everything you need to know to make a pattern like this! If this picture inspires you, try to make something similar. Otherwise, create something all your own. Notice: We've used the `set alpha` block to make the "petals" fade toward the outside.
markdown_instructions.Bergeron Robot Maze1_markdown_instructio:
Can you help me catch the naughty pig? 

Stack a couple of `move forward` blocks below the `when run` block and press "Run".
markdown_instructions.Big Game Animation 1_markdown_instructio: Now that you've learned to write simple linear functions, let's work on using them to add some movement to our game. Click "Run" to see what your game can currently do (not much!), update any variables you like, and then click finish to move on.
markdown_instructions.Big Game Animation 2_markdown_instructio:
The `update-target` function takes the target's current x value, and returns an updated value.

Complete `update-target` so that it adds to the x value each time it is called. The more you add to x, the faster the target will go.
markdown_instructions.Big Game Animation 3_markdown_instructio:
The `update-danger` function should work just like `update-target`, except that the danger should move from the right side over towards the left.

Complete `update-danger` to make the danger fly across the screen.
markdown_instructions.Big Game Animation 4_markdown_instructio:
At this point in your game your danger should run across the screen from right to left, and your target should run across from left to right.

They don't ever come back on screen once they've left, but we'll take care of that later.

Take a minute to make sure your game is working like you want it to, and then click "Finish" to move on.
markdown_instructions.Big Game Booleans 1_markdown_instruction: When you last worked on your game we got our target and danger sprites to fly across the screen, but they never come back. Click "Run" to see how your game is currently working, and then click finish and we'll work on making those sprites reappear on screen after they've left.
markdown_instructions.Big Game Booleans 2_markdown_instruction:
Now that your `onscreen?` function is checking `safe-left?` and `safe-right?` we need to fix those functions.

When we used them for Sam the Bat we wanted to prevent Sam from leaving the screen, but now we want the Target and Danger to actually go all the way off screen before returning to the opposite side.

Go to the "Functions" section of the toolbox and complete the `safe-left?` function so that it returns *true* if the sprite's x coordinate is greater than -50.

If you're successful you should see the Danger go all the way off the left side before returning on the right side.
markdown_instructions.Big Game Booleans 3_markdown_instruction:
Now that you've got `safe-left?` working, let's fix `safe-right?`

It should take in a sprite's x coordinate and return true if that coordinate is less than 450.

Once your `safe-right?` is complete you should see the Target go off the right side of the screen and return on the left.
markdown_instructions.Big Game Booleans 4_markdown_instruction:
We've provided a couple of empty functions for `safe-left?` and `safe-right?` The first thing you need to do is complete the `onscreen?` function so that it checks whether both `safe-left?` and `safe-right?` are true.

**TIP** - even after you add `safe-left?` and `safe-right?` your sprites won't return to the screen - why do you think that is?
markdown_instructions.Big Game Booleans 5_markdown_instruction: At this point your Danger should run across the screen from right to left, your Target should run across from left to right, and they should both return to the opposite side, repeatedly. Take a minute to make sure your game is working like you want it to, and then click "Finish" to move on.
markdown_instructions.Big Game Collision 1_markdown_instructio: At this point you've programmed a video game with a moving Target and Danger, both of which return to the screen once they've left, and a Player that responds to keyboard input. Click "Run" to see how your game is currently working, and then we'll dig into the final missing piece - collision detection!
markdown_instructions.Big Game Collision 3_markdown_instructio:
Let's fix this `distance` function so our collision detection works properly.

Use the Distance Formula, so the distance function returns the distance between the player's center coordinates (px, py) and another sprite's center coordinates (cx, cy).

We've provided a working `line-length` function to help you out.
markdown_instructions.Big Game Collision 4_markdown_instructio:
The `distance` function returns the distance between two sprites.

Complete the `collide?` function so that it returns *true* if the distance between two points is less than 100 pixels apart.

If you're successful, your sprites will instantly collide - why do you think that is?
markdown_instructions.Big Game Final_markdown_instruction:
You made it!

At this point your game should be fully functioning, take some time to enjoy your new game and make any final tweaks to it.

When you're happy with the final product, click Finish and you'll have an opportunity to share a link to your game.

Good work!
markdown_instructions.Big Game Player 1_markdown_instruction:
We're getting really close to a finished game!

Last time you worked on your game, you used booleans to make your Target and Danger return to the screen once they've left. Click "Run" to see how your game looks right now, and then we'll get to making your Player move up and down.
markdown_instructions.Big Game Player 2_markdown_instruction:
To move the player up and down, we'll need to use a conditional block to figure out which key is pressed and respond accordingly.

Computers read keypresses as numeric key codes - the up arrow is **38** and the down arrow is **40**. You can lookup other key codes in your student workbook.

Edit the `update-player` function so the player moves up when the up arrow (keycode 38) is pressed, and moves down (keycode 40) when the down arrow is pressed.
markdown_instructions.Big Game Vars 1_markdown_instruction: Let's get started on your Big Game! Here you'll see a whole bunch of placeholder code that you'll eventually replace with your own, but for now we're only going to worry about defining variables. Click "Run" to see what the game looks like with the default values.
markdown_instructions.Big Game Vars 2_markdown_instruction: The first step to making this game your own is to give it a good Title. Click edit on the `title` and `subtitle` variables and change them to something new.
markdown_instructions.Big Game Vars 3_markdown_instruction: Now let's set the background for your new game. Edit the `bg` variable and select a new background Image from the dropdown.
markdown_instructions.Big Game Vars 4_markdown_instruction: Awesome! Now you can update the variables for your Player, Target, and Danger. Feel free to play with all of the variables at this point to make your game look like you'd like it to. Click "Finish" when you're done.

markdown_instructions.CSD-Arrays_markdown_instruction:
Today youre going to learn how to use and create **functions**.

Creating a function lets you make your own blocks! There are two parts to a function: 

Making a newly named block that has all of the code you want to run inside of it. 
-xml of function definition- 

The single green block itself that you use, or call, to run the function you created.
-xml of function call-

Prepare to get familiar with functions, learn how to edit them, and create your own!

markdown_instructions.CSDU4 - Design Mode - 1_markdown_instruc: A new group of commands has been added to the toolbox called **UI Controls** (User Interface Controls) which are commands that let you interact with, and respond to, the user of your app. To keep it simple, we'll start with just two commands: * `onEvent` which lets you run a function in response to some event occuring (such as a button click). * `button` which puts a button on the screen.
markdown_instructions.CSDU4 - Design Mode - 22_markdown_instru: A new command in the toolbox: `playsound`! Read the documentation about how to add sounds.

markdown_instructions.CSP U4 - First Create Record Experience_:
So how can we use this?  We can use it to compose a bunch of things we want to store at once.  In Data we call this a record.  Lets look at how we create records.new level:

View Data.

markdown_instructions.CSP U4 - Import Table_markdown_instructi:
You can create a new table by importing a CSV file. CSV stands for comma separated values and is a standard way to move data between different applications. CSV files usually have multiple columns with the first row containing the label for each column. AppLab will use this first row to create the column names in the table. 

In AppLab you can create a new table in an app by clicking the View Data button(a new browser tab opens) and type in a new, descriptive table name (the table name does not have to match the app name, and an app can have more than one table), then click the Add button next to the table name(another new browser tab opens). Click the Import button, then the Choose File button and select the RottenTomatoes2015.csv file (see below). Finally click the Overwrite & Import button. Note the unique Id field created for each record.

markdown_instructions.Calc Circles of Eval .1_markdown_instruc: Youll be writing a kind of code called Evaluation Blocks, because each block of code evaluates to a single value. Change the ??? in this code so that the block evaluates to 5.

markdown_instructions.Calc Circles of Eval .3_markdown_instruc: Here's a function for addition which takes two numbers and returns their sum. Use this Addition Block to add 3 + 6.
markdown_instructions.Calc Circles of Eval .4_markdown_instruc: Here we've nested an Addition Block inside a Multiplication Block. Complete this code so it multiplies 3 by (4 + 1)
markdown_instructions.Calc Circles of Eval 2_markdown_instruct: Use a Multiplication Block to complete this code.
markdown_instructions.Calc Circles of Eval 3_markdown_instruct: Complete the Evaluation Blocks to match this statement.
markdown_instructions.Calc Circles of Eval 4_markdown_instruct: This code is missing a couple of Evaluation Blocks - make sure you put everything in the right order.

markdown_instructions.Calc Define Funcs 1_markdown_instruction: Let's look at some more traditional algebraic functions now. Here's a function translated from the simple algebraic function `f(x) = x + 1`. What would you expect this function to output if provided an input of 15?
markdown_instructions.Calc Define Funcs 2_markdown_instruction: Write a function `f` that takes a parameter `x` and returns `x - 10`. Test your function using `f(15)`.
markdown_instructions.Calc Define Funcs 3_markdown_instruction: We don't have to call our function `f` every time; create a function called `times-ten` that should take a parameter `x` and return `x * 10`. Once you've created the function, run `times-ten(50)`.
markdown_instructions.Calc Define Funcs 4_markdown_instruction: Write a function called `half` that takes a number `x` and returns half that number. Once you've written the function, use it to calculate `half(21)`
markdown_instructions.Calc Design Recipe 1_markdown_instructio: Let's use the Design Recipe to create a function called `cube` - this function should take in a Number and return that number to the power of 3. Make sure to write two example cases! When you're done, use your new function to calculate `cube(7)`.
markdown_instructions.Calc Design Recipe 2_markdown_instructio:
Your school is holding a bake sale, and you need to track the cost of making each cookie, the money paid, and the total profit. Cookies cost $0.25 each to make, and sell for $1.50/cookie.
Write the function `cost`, which takes in the number of cookies you intend to sell, and returns the cost of making those cookies.

_Test your function by calculating the cost of 42 cookies_
markdown_instructions.Calc Design Recipe 3_markdown_instructio:
Write the function `sales` which takes in the number of cookies sold, and produces the amount of money customers spent to buy those cookies (each cookie is sold at $1.50).

_Test your function by calculating the sales for 135 cookies_
markdown_instructions.Calc Design Recipe 4_markdown_instructio:
Using the two functions we just wrote, write the function `profit`, which takes in the number of cookies you sold, and gives you back the total profit you make from selling your cookies, accounting for the cost of baking them.

_Test your function by calculating the total profit for 15 cookies_
markdown_instructions.Calc Rocket 1_markdown_instruction: In the last puzzle you wrote a contract for the function `rocket-height` that states it has a range of Number, domain of Number, and should return the height of the rocket traveling at 15 m/s after a given number of seconds. Let's write an example case now for the height of the rocket at 3 seconds.
markdown_instructions.Calc Rocket 2_markdown_instruction: Great, let's do one more example before writing the function - what should the rocket height be after 30 seconds?

markdown_instructions.Course 4 Artist Binary ryan_markdown_ins:
Binary is a way of representing information using only two options.  Here, we're going to use the options "off" (represented by the number 0) and "on" (represented by the number 1).   

We've provided you with a grid of "pixels" that you can walk through and make designs by turning on only certain squares.  Can you have the artist draw "01010101" in binary in the first row?

markdown_instructions.Course 4 Artist For Loops 11_markdown_in:
Remember back in a previous stage when we used a variable to control the number of sides in a shape? We are going to do the same thing with the `counter` variable now.  

This pattern starts with a triangle and adds one side at a time until it draws a decagon (10 sides). Each side should be 100 pixels long.

markdown_instructions.Course 4 Artist For Loops 11a_markdown_i:

markdown_instructions.Course 4 Artist For Loops 13_markdown_in: Hmmm, those shapes are getting bigger every time! Didn't we already solve this problem with variables? markdown_instructions.Course 4 Artist Vars 13_markdown_instruc:
When a shape has lots of sides, each side needs to be shorter if you want the whole pattern to fit on the screen. 

Let's recreate the algorithm for this amazing pattern, but instead of manually setting the `length` variable, let's use a math block with the `sides` variable inside to make sure that each shape fits correctly.  

The perimeter of each polygon is 300 pixels.

For even more effect, try playing with color!  Use random colors inside loops to see how it changes your design.

The bee can't tell what's under the cloud! 

Use the `if` block to check whether there is a flower under the cloud.

markdown_instructions.Course 4 Bee 2_markdown_instruction:
Use the `if/else` block to check each object to see if it's a flower or a honeycomb. 

If it's a flower, collect one nectar...otherwise, make one honey!
markdown_instructions.Course 4 Bee 3_markdown_instruction:
The unknown object is either a flower or a honeycomb. 

This time, use the `if/else` block to collect one nectar **if** it is a flower, **else** make one honey (because then it would be a honeycomb).
markdown_instructions.Course 4 Bee 4_markdown_instruction:
This purple flower may have either 3, 2, or 1 nectar. 

Here an `if/else` block is combined with another `if/else` block to create an `if/else-if/else` statement.

markdown_instructions.Course 4 Bee 5_markdown_instruction: This purple flower may have either 3, 2, or 1 nectar. Add an `if-else` block to create an `if, else-if, else` block. Complete the solution to collect the unknown amount of nectar.
markdown_instructions.Course 4 Bee 6_markdown_instruction: This purple flower may have either 3, 2, or 1 nectar. Create an `if, else-if, else` block to collect the unknown amount of nectar.

markdown_instructions.Course 4 Bee Params 5_markdown_instructi: Let's start from scratch - can you create a new function called `get 5 nectar` with a direction parameter?

markdown_instructions.Course 4 Play Lab Params 1_markdown_inst:
Here's a function called `jump` that causes your main character to jump up 100 pixels. 

Run the program and use the jump function to collect all of the flags by moving the dog with the arrow keys.
markdown_instructions.Course 4 Play Lab Params 2_markdown_inst:
Now we've got flags that are too high for our current jump! Let's use both the "up" and "down" arrows so that we can have multiple jump heights.  

We need to add a parameter to our jump function called `height`.  
- The up arrow should cause the dog to jump 200 pixels 
- The down arrow should make it jump only 100 pixels.
markdown_instructions.Course 4 Play Lab Params 4_markdown_inst:
Here's a function called `patrol`. 

Edit `patrol` to move Cat up 400 pixels and then down 400 pixels.
markdown_instructions.Course 4 Play Lab Params 5_markdown_inst: Edit the the `patrol` function to add an `actor` parameter, so that we can call it for each of the actors on the screen. Remember, the actors correspond to numbers 1, 2, and 3.
markdown_instructions.Course 4 Play Lab Params 6_markdown_inst: Add another parameter called `speed` to the `patrol` function. Try using a `set speed` block with the new `speed` parameter to help Penguin get both flags before the other sprites even get one.
markdown_instructions.Course 4 Play Lab Params 7_markdown_inst:
Let's have some fun! Look at the code provided to see if you can figure out what each block does.  

When you're done, use the arrow keys to control Dog and collect all of the flags.

**NOTE:** You don't need to make any changes to the program
markdown_instructions.Course 4 Play Lab Params 8_markdown_inst: Use the `when actor touches` block to send Dog back to the top-left ONLY if Dog touches any of the other actors.
markdown_instructions.Course 4 Play Lab Vars 2_markdown_instru: The race in that last puzzle wasn't very fair! Change the `dog_speed` variable to make sure you can collect more flags than Cat. The first to collect 10 flags wins!
markdown_instructions.Course 4 Play Lab Vars 3_markdown_instru:
Here's a new kind of game! 

You don't need to change anything on this level.

**Directions:** Use the left and right arrows to move, and the up arrow to jump. See if you can collect all of the flags.
markdown_instructions.Course 4 Play Lab Vars 4_markdown_instru: Now we're using a variable called `height` to control how high the dog can jump. Update the `height` variable so that the dog can jump high enough to reach all the flags.
markdown_instructions.Course 4 Play Lab Vars 7_markdown_instru:
Nice, now let's make sure this game isn't too easy to play!  

Any time Dog (actor 1) gets hit by a sandwich from Cat (actor 2), you should lose a point. 

Start with 10 points so it's not too hard. Let your score drop down from 10 to 0 to pass the level.
markdown_instructions.Course 4 Play Lab Vars 9_markdown_instru:
Free Play time! Here are all of the variables we've played with so far in this stage, as well as a few more in case you want them. 

Notice that there are now so many blocks in our toolbox that they need to be organized!  Here, we've put each piece into an appropriate category.  Take some time to explore everything that is available. When you're done browsing, make a game or story using repeats, variables, and events.  

*Hint: scroll down to see all the commands in the workspace.*
markdown_instructions.Course 4 Play Labs For Loops 1_markdown_: Let's make the dog speak every number from 1 to 100. Use a `for` loop and the counter block to speak the counter variable each time the loop is run.
markdown_instructions.Course 4 Play Labs For Loops 4a_markdown:
Now, let's blend the variables from Stage 7 together with your `counter` variable to make some magic happen.   

In this puzzle, Dog will count from **0** to **1000** by `increment`.  Set the `increment` variable to **10** at the beginning of your code to see what happens.
markdown_instructions.Course 4 Play Labs For Loops 5_markdown_: In the last stage we counted the square of each number. Try changing `counter ^ 2` to `counter ^ 3` to count the cube of each number (1, 8, 27, 64, 125, 216, 343)
markdown_instructions.Course 4 Play Labs For Loops 5a_markdown:
In this puzzle, Dog will be your time keeper.

Dog will count from **0** to **30** by `increment`.  The `increment` variable will begin with a value of **1**.

Can you make it so that each time you click Dog, `increment` increases by **2**?  Click the forward arrow to run the `for loop`.  

**Note:** Run the loop a couple of times, clicking Dog before each one.
markdown_instructions.Course 4 Play Labs For Loops 6a_markdown:
Now that we've seen how to control our `for loop` using variables inside of our program, let's make a game!

Dog will still keep time by counting with our `for loop` by `increment`, but this time we will add The Wizard into the mix.  Can you change the code so that `increment` goes up by two each time The Wizard is clicked?

Watch out!  The Wizard moves quickly!
markdown_instructions.Course 4 Play Labs For Loops 7a_markdown:
Now we're getting somewhere!  What if we start counting how many times we can click The Wizard before Dog gets to 30?  

Finish adding blocks to The Wizard so that every time he's clicked the variable `clicked` increases by one. You can ignore `increment` for now.

**Note:** Dog will start counting when you click `Run`.
markdown_instructions.Course 4 Play Labs For Loops 8_markdown_:
Now, help the actors move as they count.  

Dog should move and count by adding 2 (`counter + 2`) each time.  Cat will move and count by multiplying by 2 (`counter *2`)  each time. Penguin will move and count to the power of 2 (`counter ^ 2`) each time.  Who will reach their flag first?
markdown_instructions.Course 4 Playlab For Loop Freeplay_markd: **Freeplay:** Use everything you've learned so far to make a game that includes a `for` loop!
markdown_instructions.Course 4 Playlab For Loops 4b_markdown_i:
Now, these two characters are going to race!  

Each of them will move `counter` steps at a time, but their counters will have different values because of the `for` loops.  

Can you change the **increment** in one of the loops so that the race is a tie?
markdown_instructions.Course 4 Playlab For Loops 5b_markdown_i: Adjust the interval on these `for` loops so that the two characters end in the exact same place.
markdown_instructions.Course 4 Playlab For Loops 6b_markdown_i:
Now we're going to use `for` loops in a whole different way!

This game gets hard quickly because the time between disappearances shrinks fast!

<hr/>

**Edit this `for` loop to create a game that's fun for you to play!**  

<hr/>

Press "Run" and click Madame Unicorn as many times as you can.  Can you beat our score of 24?

markdown_instructions.CourseF_PlayLab_vars10_markdown_instruct:
Free Play time! Here are all of the variables we've played with so far in this stage, as well as a few more in case you want them. 

Notice that there are now so many blocks in our toolbox that they need to be organized!  Here, we've put each piece into an appropriate category.  Take some time to explore everything that is available. When you're done browsing, make a game or story using repeats, variables, and events.  

*Hint: scroll down to see all the commands in the workspace.*
markdown_instructions.CourseF_PlayLab_vars2_markdown_instructi: The race in that last puzzle wasn't very fair! Change the `dog_speed` variable to make sure you can collect more flags than Cat. The first to collect 10 flags wins!
markdown_instructions.CourseF_PlayLab_vars3_markdown_instructi:
Here's a new kind of game! 

You don't need to change anything on this level.

**Directions:** Use the left and right arrows to move, and the up arrow to jump. See if you can collect all of the flags.
markdown_instructions.CourseF_PlayLab_vars4_markdown_instructi: Now we're using a variable called `height` to control how high the dog can jump. Update the `height` variable so that the dog can jump high enough to reach all the flags.
markdown_instructions.CourseF_PlayLab_vars9_markdown_instructi:
Nice, now let's make sure this game isn't too easy to play!  

Any time Dog (actor 1) gets hit by a sandwich from Cat (actor 2), you should lose a point. 

Start with 10 points so it's not too hard. Let your score drop down from 10 to 0 to pass the level.
markdown_instructions.D_Frozen_nested4_markdown_instruction:
![](https://images.code.org/109aa2afaa3b7b1ecebff518bacdf3c5-image-1500660008987.png) _"What happens if we draw snowflakes on top of each other?"_

Try layering two different shapes of snowflakes on top of one another with a little turn in between - see what you get!
markdown_instructions.D_Frozen_nested5_markdown_instruction: ![](https://images.code.org/109aa2afaa3b7b1ecebff518bacdf3c5-image-1500660008987.png) _"Get creative with shapes and angles to see what kind of new snowflakes we can draw!"_
markdown_instructions.D_Frozen_nested7_markdown_instruction:
![](https://images.code.org/109aa2afaa3b7b1ecebff518bacdf3c5-image-1500660008987.png) _"Now lets turn and go back the way we came."_

Turn around 180 degrees and draw the exact same stair pattern again!  

- The rest of this stage will be easier if you put all of your code inside of a loop to make Elsa  draw, turn around 180 degrees, draw, then turn around 180 degrees again.

<hr/>

Here is an example of stairs that use a 76 degree turn:

![](https://images.code.org/ceea66fad37e79cc45a850911f90440c-image-1496696286635.16.27.png)
markdown_instructions.D_Frozen_nested9_markdown_instruction:
![](https://images.code.org/109aa2afaa3b7b1ecebff518bacdf3c5-image-1500660008987.png)  _"Now, what should we do? Lets explore and create our own winter wonderland!"_

Try playing around with what you've created. Draw whatever you like!
- What happens if you use two different angles in your stair step pattern?
- What happens if you make your diamond pattern longer or shorter?
- What does it look like to draw two snowflakes on top of one another?

markdown_instructions.ECSPD Online U1D1-2 Assessment 1_markdow: Did you have coffee this morning? If you did, odds are you used a computer. If you made the coffee yourself, your coffee maker probably had a digital clock or a programmable timer. If you bought it, the barista likely used a card reader with an electronic cash register to take your payment. Think through your day and record how many computers you used before sitting down in front of a desktop or a laptop (or whatever device you are using right now). Don't forget the computers in your car, your refrigerator, your alarm clock...
markdown_instructions.ECSPD Online U1D1-2 Reflection_markdown_: You have experienced the lesson both online and on the first day of the in-person PD. Additionally, you have watched a video defining computers. What have you learned that you can take back to your classroom? Use this space to record your ideas for this lesson. You will have a chance to share your ideas and questions in a forum in the following level.

markdown_instructions.ECSPD your goals_markdown_instruction: __What are your goals for your ECS class?__ *These goals will change over time, and we'll revisit this your response as we go through the course so we can check in on how we're progressing towards those goals.*
markdown_instructions.Eval Booleans 1_markdown_instruction: Boolean operators (like >, <, =) allow us to compare different values, returning either *true* or *false*. Click "Run" to see how this expression evaluates.
markdown_instructions.Eval Booleans 2_markdown_instruction: Can you set the values so that this expression evaluates as *true*?
markdown_instructions.Eval Booleans 3_markdown_instruction: The `string-length` function returns the number of characters in a string (including spaces!) - make this code evaluate to *true*.
markdown_instructions.Eval Booleans 4_markdown_instruction: Here's an Evaluation Block called `and` - it returns *true* if both of its parameters are *true*, otherwise it returns *false*. Edit the x variable so that this expression returns *true*.
markdown_instructions.Eval Booleans 5_markdown_instruction: This `or` block returns *true* if either of its parameters is *true*. Otherwise, if both parameters are *false* it will return *false*. Set the y variable to a value that will cause this expression to return *false*.
markdown_instructions.Eval Booleans 6_markdown_instruction: Here's one more boolean block called `not`. This block flips *true* to *false*, or *false* to *true*. If you wrap this block of code in a NOT block, it should return *true* (because we are asking if the two expressions do NOT produce equal values).
markdown_instructions.Eval Booleans Free Play_markdown_instruc: Free Play: Try out some creations of your own using Booleans.
markdown_instructions.Eval Cond 4_markdown_instruction: We can use the `string=?` function to make conditionals that respond to text input. Here's a function called `green shape` that takes a string for the type of shape. Complete the conditions so that the correct solid green shape is returned when the function is run with "circle", "triangle", "square", or "rectangle".
markdown_instructions.Eval Cond 5_markdown_instruction: Here's a similar function `red shape` with an additional variable for size. Complete the conditionals so the correct solid red image of a given size is drawn for "circle", "triangle", and "star".
markdown_instructions.Eval Contracts 4_markdown_instruction: The `scale` function returns an image that is either larger or smaller than the input image. Try scaling this circle by a factor of 10. How is the returned image different than if you'd just made a circle of that size in the first place?
markdown_instructions.Eval Contracts A_markdown_instruction: Use the `star` function to produce a solid red star with a 60 pixel radius
markdown_instructions.Eval Contracts C_markdown_instruction: Check out the `rotate` function - can you use it to rotate this 90 pixel green square by 45 degrees?
markdown_instructions.Eval Contracts E_markdown_instruction: Try using the `text` function to write this "Hello, world!" in teal at size 40.
markdown_instructions.Eval Define Funcs 1_markdown_instruction: Here's a new function called `green-triangle` that takes a single Number for size and produces a green triangle. Use the new function to create a 125 pixel green triangle
markdown_instructions.Eval Define Funcs 2_markdown_instruction: Let's look inside that `green-triangle` function to see how it works. Can you modify it so that the `green-triangle` function always draws outlined green triangles? **Don't forget to change the examples too!**
markdown_instructions.Eval Define Funcs 3_markdown_instruction:
Here's the start of another new function called `purple-circle` with a domain of one Number (the radius) and a range of Image. The body of the function is broken though, it always draws a circle of 50 pixel radius instead of using the radius parameter. Replace the current Number with the `radius` block from the domain.

When you've fixed the function, test your new function with a 150 pixel radius.
markdown_instructions.Eval Define Funcs 4_markdown_instruction: Create a new function called `aqua-star` that has a Domain of a single Number for radius and returns an aqua star of the given radius. Run your new function with a radius of 75.
markdown_instructions.Eval Define Funcs 5_markdown_instruction: Let's use that `aqua-star` function to make a row of different sized stars. From left to right, the stars should have radii of 25, 50, and 75.
markdown_instructions.Eval Define Funcs Test_markdown_instruct:
Here's the start of another new function called `purple-circle` with a domain of one Number (the radius) and a range of Image. The body of the function is broken though, it always draws a circle of 50 pixel radius instead of using the radius parameter. Replace the current Number with the `radius` block from the domain.

When you've fixed the function, test your new function with a 150 pixel radius.
markdown_instructions.Eval Defining Vars Free Play 1_markdown_: Free Play: We've provided a function that fills your screen with `my-image`. Change `my-image` to see what patterns you can make.
markdown_instructions.Eval Design Recipe .1_markdown_instructi: Here's a Design Recipe for a function called `square-circle` with domain Number String and range Image. Click Edit to write the function definition (you will see two examples provided).
markdown_instructions.Eval Design Recipe 3_markdown_instructio: The Design Recipe for `wide-rect` already has a contract and one example. Can you write a second example and then complete the definition? The `wide-rect` function should produce a rectangle of given color that is twice as wide as it is high.
markdown_instructions.Eval Design Recipe 4_markdown_instructio: Use the Design Recipe to create a function `starburst`. When given a number of points and an outer radius, `starburst` returns a yellow radial star with given points, and an inner radius that is half the outer radius.
markdown_instructions.Eval Design Recipe 5_markdown_instructio: Write a function `striped-flag` that takes two colors and produces a flag that is 250 pixels wide, 150 pixels tall, with three even horizontal stripes of given colors, in the order color2, color1, color2.
markdown_instructions.Eval Design Recipe 6_markdown_instructio: Write a function `large-polygon` that should output a solid polygon of given sides and color that takes up most of the window, regardless of the number of sides. To make sure that the polygon doesn't get too large as you increase the number of sides, side length should be inversely proportional to side number, with a length of **(800/sides)**.
markdown_instructions.Eval Design Recipe Free Play_markdown_in: Free Play: Use the Design Recipe to create some functions of your own design
markdown_instructions.Eval Strings Images .1_markdown_instruct: So far we've only dealt with a single type of data, Numbers. Another type of data is a String, which is any combination of letters, numbers, or other characters wrapped in quotation marks. Run the String "Hello, world!" and see what happens.
markdown_instructions.Eval Strings Images .2_markdown_instruct: The `string-append` function takes two Strings and returns a single combined String. Add a String "Universe" to the second argument of `string-append`.
markdown_instructions.Eval Strings Images 1_markdown_instructi: The third type of data we're going to use is an Image. This `star` function takes in a Number and two Strings, and it evaluates to an Image. Use this function to make a solid red star with radius of 100.
markdown_instructions.Eval Strings Images 2_markdown_instructi: Free Play: Every Evaluation Block is color-coded to let you know which data type it returns and which types it needs for its parameters. The last parameter of the triangle function takes a String that controls its color - try some different colors to see what works.
markdown_instructions.Eval Strings Images 3_markdown_instructi: Some functions can only take a specific set of Strings, such as the second argument of this `circle` function, which controls its style. Draw this orange outline circle using the special String block with a dropdown to make sure you only use valid styles.
markdown_instructions.Eval Strings Images 4_markdown_instructi: Try using the `rectangle` block to draw this solid, red rectangle - it is 175 pixels wide and 100 pixels tall.
markdown_instructions.Eval Strings Images 5_markdown_instructi: Try using this new Evaluation Block called `overlay` to place a 100 pixel white triangle on top of a 200 pixel red circle.
markdown_instructions.Eval Strings Images 6_markdown_instructi: Use the overlay block to place a 75 pixel radius yellow star on top of a 150 pixel long blue square.
markdown_instructions.Eval Strings Images 7_markdown_instructi: The `offset` block lets you move an image relative to where it would normally be placed. Use this block to offset the square by 100 pixels on the y-axis.
markdown_instructions.Eval Strings Images 8_markdown_instructi: Here's a different kind of star block - it's called `radial-star` and it allows you to draw stars with any number of points! Use it to create a 7 point solid orange star with an inner radius of 75 pixels and an outer radius of 175 pixels.
markdown_instructions.Eval Strings Images Free Play_markdown_i: Free Play: Explore the blocks available to create something interesting. Make sure to share your favorite creations.

markdown_instructions.Function intro Ryan_markdown_instruction:
A **function** named `build bridge` is in your workspace.  All of the code you need to cross the river is built right in! 
 
Snap the small, green <xml> <block type="procedures_callnoreturn" id="callMe"><mutation name="build bridge"/></block></xml> block into your workspace twice to fix the path and get {currentPlayerName} to the Redstone Torch [redstone_torch].
markdown_instructions.GLJ_Crawl_Exemplar_1_markdown_instructio: **Free Play**: Try using what you've learned to make something new. Make sure to explore some of the new blocks in the toolbox.
markdown_instructions.GLJr_Behavior_7_markdown_instruction:
Check out these two new blocks - the green "When dog is touching cat" block will run everything attached to it when the dog touches the cat, and the "Remove behavior" block removes a behavior from a sprite.

See if you can make both the dog and cat stop moving when they run into each other.
markdown_instructions.GLJr_Behavior_8_markdown_instruction: The cat and dog are so excited to see each other that they want to have a dance party. In addition to removing their move behaviors when the two sprites touch, add the "dance party" behavior so they celebrate!
markdown_instructions.GLJr_Behavior_9_markdown_instruction: **Free Play**: Try using what you've learned to make something new. Make sure to explore some of the new blocks in the toolbox.
markdown_instructions.GLJr_Forever_5_markdown_instruction: Now we have two sprites! Use a loop to make the dog jittery and make the cat wander
markdown_instructions.GLJr_Forever_6_markdown_instruction: Let's try some more movement blocks - make the dog run up and make the cat run right.
markdown_instructions.GLJr_Forever_7_markdown_instruction:
Check out this new "if-else" block - it lets you run one set of code _if_ a condition is true, and a different set of code if it's false. Inside it we're using another new block that tells you _if_ two sprites are touching.

See if you can make both the dog and cat stop moving when they run into each other.
markdown_instructions.GLJr_Forever_8_markdown_instruction: The cat and dog are so excited to see each other that they want to have a dance party. If the two sprites are touching, have each run the "dance party" block.
markdown_instructions.GLJr_Forever_9_markdown_instruction: **Free Play**: Try using what you've learned to make something new. Make sure to explore some of the new blocks in the toolbox.

Every sprout could grow up to be **corn** ![picture of corn](https://images.code.org/cac3133c40781553a70066a67298b2b5-image-1472493202556.png) , **beans** ![picture of beans](https://images.code.org/5e379ff595be17722237d9685b29fd96-image-1472493220871.png) , or **pumpkins** ![picture of pumpkin](https://images.code.org/03cf76a978e0788ccb53f14e9d264695-image-1472493237148.png) . Can you write some code to pick all the crops, no matter what they are?

markdown_instructions.Luigi's Pizza 1_markdown_instruction: Welcome to Luigi's Pizza! To order a pizza, type the name of a topping into the `cost` function, and we'll return the price of that pizza. Try ordering a pepperoni pizza to start.
markdown_instructions.Luigi's Pizza 2_markdown_instruction: Right now there are only four choices available at Luigi's pizza - let's fix that! Add a couple of new toppings to the conditional block in the `cost` function. Once you've added your toppings, test out the function to make sure it works.
markdown_instructions.Luigi's Pizza 3_markdown_instruction: That's better, everyone loves more variety in their pizza toppings! But you still can't please everyone, and folks are coming in to order toppings that Luigi doesn't have. Instead of saying no to those people, could you update the _else_ clause so that we charge them a premium for toppings that we don't normally offer? Let's charge $10,000 for a topping we don't carry.
markdown_instructions.Luigi's Pizza 4_markdown_instruction:
Free Play: What can you do to make Luigi's cost function even more useful? Try one (or more) of the following:  

- Create a new function to display an image of the chosen pizza
- Create a function that allows for ordering multiple pizzas (the same, or with different toppings)
- Create a function that allows you to add a coupon code for a 30% discount
markdown_instructions.MC Agent Freeplay_markdown_instruction: **Freeplay:** Now it's up to you! Use the Agent's code to help you explore this world.
markdown_instructions.MC HOC 2016 SCORE LEVEL_markdown_instruc:
Some games let you keep score. Play tag with these Iron Golems and use the <xml>  <block type="craft_addScore">
    <title name="SCORE">1</title>
  </block></xml> block to give yourself a point when you tag them.  
  
  Reach five points to win!
markdown_instructions.MC_2017_Ryan_02_markdown_instruction:
Code like this can be made even shorter using loops!  

Now get the Agent to the pressure plate using a `repeat` loop to help him move forward.
markdown_instructions.MC_HOC_2017 Agent Test_markdown_instruct:
Click "Run" to move the player using the **arrow keys**.  

To pass this level, you will need to get to the door and open it (using the **space bar**) so you can get to the orange square inside.
markdown_instructions.MC_HOC_2017_01_markdown_instruction:
Click "Run" to move the player using the **arrow keys**.  

To pass this level, you will need to get to the door and open it (using the **space bar**) so you can get to the orange square inside.
markdown_instructions.MC_HOC_2017_01_Cole_markdown_instruction: You need to collect all the tools on this journey. Move around using the **arrow keys**, and get to the chest on the path to win
markdown_instructions.MC_HOC_2017_01_Kiki_markdown_instruction: To play this level, click the orange "Run" button beneath the play space, then move the player around using the **arrow keys**.
markdown_instructions.MC_HOC_2017_01_RETRY_markdown_instructio:
The door is locked, but the Agent is here to help!

Snap a `move forward` block to the bottom of the `when run` block in the workspace to get the Agent to the pressure plate [PressurePlate_Up], then press "Run" and use the arrow keys to move out of the house to collect the **chest** [chest].
markdown_instructions.MC_HOC_2017_02_markdown_instruction: The player needs to get into that secret grove.  Help The Agent open the gate by writing code to get him to the pressure plate.
markdown_instructions.MC_HOC_2017_02_Cole_markdown_instruction:
{currentPlayerName} is headed on an adventure! To help, get the **map** [map_empty] behind the locked door on the right. 
 
Snap the code into the workspace to move the Agent to the pressure plate [PressurePlate_Up] so that {currentPlayerName} can get through.
markdown_instructions.MC_HOC_2017_02_Kiki_markdown_instruction:
The player is headed out on an adventure, but first they have to get the torch that is hidden on the other side of that locked door. 

Program the Agent to move forward twice to follow the white path and get to the pressure plate so he can open the door for the player.
markdown_instructions.MC_HOC_2017_02_Will_markdown_instruction:
To finish this level, the player needs to get to the orange square inside of the Secret Grove, which is behind the locked door.  

The code in the workspace will make the Agent move forward twice to get to the pressure plate and open the door for Alex or Steve.
markdown_instructions.MC_HOC_2017_03_Cole_markdown_instruction:
{currentPlayerName} continues on the adventure and needs the **compass** [compass] to prepare for the trip.  
   
Code the Agent to open the gate.
markdown_instructions.MC_HOC_2017_03_Kiki_markdown_instruction:
The player's adventure will begin behind the locked door, in the Secret Grove!  


Help The Agent open the door by writing code to get him to the pressure plate.
markdown_instructions.MC_HOC_2017_04_markdown_instruction: Change the loop from the last puzzle to help the Agent make a path over the wider part of this river.
markdown_instructions.MC_HOC_2017_04POINT5_Cole_markdown_instr:
You made it out of the swamp!  Now, get the player safely to the orange square.

Help The Agent clear the path by finding a simple pattern and using loops to cross the first two pressure plates.
markdown_instructions.MC_HOC_2017_04POINT5_RYAN_markdown_instr:
You made it across! 

Now, get {currentPlayerName} safely through the maze to collect the **axe** [diamond_axe]
markdown_instructions.MC_HOC_2017_04_Cole_markdown_instruction:
The Agent can move across water!  
 
Use a `repeat` loop to solve this puzzle and help {currentPlayerName} get to the **bucket** [bucket_empty] behind the door.
markdown_instructions.MC_HOC_2017_04_Kiki_markdown_instruction:
The entry to the Secret Grove led to this beautiful Oasis!  To pass this level, the player needs to get to the orange square in the cabana.  

Use a `repeat` loop to help the Agent get all the way up to the pressure plate, which opens the cabana door.
markdown_instructions.MC_HOC_2017_05_markdown_instruction:
Loops are not always helpful.

These cacti are not growing in an obvious pattern, so a loop would not clear them correctly.  Instead, we've given you a function called `destroy and move` that will do the hard work for you each time the Agent gets to an obstacle.
markdown_instructions.MC_HOC_2017_05_Cole_markdown_instruction:
Oh no, the bridge is out! 

Code the Agent to rebuild the bridge using the <xml>  <block type="craft_placeBlock">
    <title name="TYPE">       </title>
  </block></xml> block so that {currentPlayerName} can get to the **shovel** [diamond_shovel].
markdown_instructions.MC_HOC_2017_05_Josh_markdown_instruction:
Oh no, the bridge is out!

Help the Agent rebuild the bridge so that the player can get to the **shovel**.
markdown_instructions.MC_HOC_2017_05_Kiki_markdown_instruction:
It's time for the player to leave the Secret Grove and continue the adventure, but the bridge is out! 

Help the Agent rebuild the bridge, then move to the wooden plank so that the player can get to the orange square.
markdown_instructions.MC_HOC_2017_06_Cole_markdown_instruction:
Another river, but this one is much wider! 
 
Fix this code to help the Agent build a bridge so that {currentPlayerName} can get to the **pickaxe** [diamond_pickaxe].
markdown_instructions.MC_HOC_2017_06_Josh_markdown_instruction:
Another river, but this one is much wider!  

Fix this code to help the Agent build a bridge across this river.
markdown_instructions.MC_HOC_2017_06_Kiki_markdown_instruction:
Another river, but this one is much wider!  

Fix this code to help the Agent build a bridge across the water.
markdown_instructions.MC_HOC_2017_07_Cole_markdown_instruction:
There's ice in the way!  
 
The `clear path` function can help you destroy the ice and get {currentPlayerName} to the Minecart [minecart_normal]!
markdown_instructions.MC_HOC_2017_07_Kiki_markdown_instruction:
Loops are not the only way to repeat code!  

Here, we've given you a function called `clear cacti` that will do the hard work of clearing three cacti every time you use it.  Use two `clear cacti` blocks to clear the path to the orange square.
markdown_instructions.MC_HOC_2017_07a_Kiki_markdown_instructio: Now, edit this loop to help the Agent clear a path to the orange square.
markdown_instructions.MC_HOC_2017_08_Cole_markdown_instruction:
Now, instead of destroying before you move, you will need to place a block.  

Change the provided function to work for the desert.
markdown_instructions.MC_HOC_2017_08_Kiki_markdown_instruction:
Now, instead of destroying cacti, you will need to place stone over lava, then destroy standstone.  

Change the function to work for this level.
markdown_instructions.MC_HOC_2017_08_RY_markdown_instruction:
Now there are **TWO** functions to choose from!

Use these functions to quickly build a bridge across the lava for {currentPlayerName}.
markdown_instructions.MC_HOC_2017_08_Will_markdown_instruction:
Now there are **TWO** functions to choose from!

Use these functions to quickly build a bridge across the lava for the player.
markdown_instructions.MC_HOC_2017_09_Cole_markdown_instruction: Use functions to help the Agent destroy the giant blocks of dirt that are blocking the player's path to the pressure plate.
markdown_instructions.MC_HOC_2017_09_Kiki_markdown_instruction:
This starting code cannot be removed.

Add commands to the `create trail` function so that the program in the workspace will get the Agent to the pressure plate.
markdown_instructions.MC_HOC_2017_09_RS_CLONE_markdown_instruc: Fix this function to fill in the holes, then step on the pressure plate to clear a path to the torch.
markdown_instructions.MC_HOC_2017_10_Cole_markdown_instruction: Use the functions to clear a path for the mine cart, and walk into the Nether Portal.

Did you know that you can put more than one piece of code into a loop?  

Use a `repeat` loop to help the Agent build a bridge over the river by placing blocks in the water.

Sometimes you need to knock down things that get in the way of your player.  
Use the `destroy` block to clear all of the cactii between the Agent and the pressure plate.

markdown_instructions.MSM Defining Vars 1_markdown_instruction: Write a program that produces a 50 pixel solid green triangle.
markdown_instructions.MSM Defining Vars 2_markdown_instruction: If we wanted to make fifty green triangles, it would be a pain to repeat that block of code 50 times. Let's create a variable called `my-shape` and put the code for a 50 pixel solid green triangle inside.
markdown_instructions.MSM Defining Vars 3_markdown_instruction: Take your `my-shape` variable and use it with this provided code to draw two identical green triangles that are 50 pixels in size.
markdown_instructions.MSM Defining Vars 4_markdown_instruction: Edit your `my-shape` variable so that it draws 75 pixel solid red stars.
markdown_instructions.Making Music_markdown_instruction:
Today youre going to learn how to use and create **functions**.

Creating a function lets you make your own blocks! There are two parts to a function: 

Making a newly named block that has all of the code you want to run inside of it. 
-xml of function definition- 

The single green block itself that you use, or call, to run the function you created.
-xml of function call-

Prepare to get familiar with functions, learn how to edit them, and create your own!

Check to see if there's a flower under the cloud, and only get nectar if there's a flower.

markdown_instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 1_markdown: Can you draw a square that is 100 pixels in length, using a repeat loop?
markdown_instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 10.1_markd: Use the functions from the previous puzzles to draw this pattern.
markdown_instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 10_markdow: Click "edit" to fill out the blocks in the function definition to make a 40 pixel square.
markdown_instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 11_markdow:
Now we want to create a new function called `draw a line of squares` that draws six squares all in a row. Can you build this function using this `draw a square 20` function that we created for you?

*Note: See that we've changed the pen to be much thinner. Click "edit" on the `draw a square 20` function to see how!*
markdown_instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 12_markdow: Use the `draw a line of squares` function from the last puzzle to draw this pattern.
markdown_instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 13_markdow:
Can you draw a star shape using the `draw a line of squares` function?  

(Be sure to `move forward` 60 pixels before you turn 144 degrees!)
markdown_instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 14_markdow: It's free-play time! Draw anything you like!
markdown_instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 2_markdown:
Can you draw 3 squares 20 pixels apart from one another? 

Each square is 100 pixels in size.
markdown_instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 3_markdown:
Here is a new type of Block. It is called a `function` block. Click "edit" then fill it with the code for drawing a square with 100 pixel sides. 

When you're done editing the function, click "Close" to go back to your program.
markdown_instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 4_markdown: Use the `draw a square` function to draw this pattern.
markdown_instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 6_markdown: Using the "draw a square" function block, can you draw this picture? Hint: each square is 20 pixels apart.
markdown_instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 7_markdown:
Are you getting the hang of how to use function blocks? Let's modify `draw a square` so that it draws squares that are 200 pixels in size. 

Click on "edit" to enter the `draw a square` function editor.

Remember to click on "Close" to get out of the function editor.
markdown_instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 8_markdown: We have created a new function for you called `draw a triangle`.  Can you edit the function definition to draw a triangle with 100 pixel sides?
markdown_instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 9_markdown: Can you solve this by adding only one block?

This hexagon has sides that are 100 pixels in length.
markdown_instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Params 11_markdown_i:
Can you figure out how to draw this shape? 

Edit the function to use the `sides` parameter.
markdown_instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Params 12_markdown_i:

The sides of all the shapes are 100 pixels long.
markdown_instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Params 12a_markdown_:

markdown_instructions.NEW Course 4 Bee For Loops 3_markdown_in: Ah, the `for loop` makes this much easier! All the code you need is here, take a look at how it is put together then click `Run` to see how it works.

markdown_instructions.NEW Course 4 Bee For Loops 6_markdown_in:

markdown_instructions.NEW Course 4 Play Lab Params 11_markdown:
It's free play time! Have fun with all the blocks in your tool box.
Need some ideas?
  • Tag - Have character 2 patrol and use your arrow keys to make character 1 chase until they collide.
  • Whack-a-Sprite - Have a character constantly pop up at a random location. Award points for clicking the sprite before it disappears.
  • Best Guess - Make both characters disappear, change location to a random spot, then reappear as a random character. Click on the first one and get a point...but if you click on the second one you LOSE a point!
