markdown_instructions.PDAlg Design Recipe Delete_markdown_inst: When developing complex programs it's not uncommon to end up with functions that you no longer want, which used to just crowd your functions drawer, but now you can **delete** them. Click the **delete** button to get rid of this function, then try creating and deleting a few of your own.
markdown_instructions.PDAlg Design Recipe Required_markdown_in: In addition to testing examples, we can also _require_ that students use examples in their functions. Complete the Design Recipe for the `eggs` function, making sure to create and test your examples. (You can ignore creating examples if you want to see the error message.)
markdown_instructions.PDAlg Updates Cond_markdown_instruction:
When you went to PD in the summer, the **Conditional** block that you were introduced to was black and allowed any data type to be used. This proved to be confusing, given that every other function we've seen always produces the same type of data. To help make conditionals clearer and more consistent we've replaced the single black block with a separate block for each data type.

![conditional blocks](//studio.code.org/script_assets/pd/newcond.png)
markdown_instructions.PDAlg Updates Errors_markdown_instructio:
Few things in programming are as frustrating as ambiguous or unclear error messages. When things go wrong in a program we rely on helpful error messages for direction, so we've spend a lot of time creating error messages that help direct students to solve their own problems.

Run the provided program and use the error messages to try and track down the bugs.
markdown_instructions.PDAlg Updates Space_markdown_instruction:
Making use of limited programming space (especially on small screens) is challenging with a block based language. To help with this we've added a few features:

- A draggable bar (three vertical dots) between the programming space and the game space allowing you to shrink the game space for more room to code.
- A handful of redesigned blocks that take up less horizontal space (check out the new `overlay` block.)
- The programming space will scroll vertically when the blocks extend past the visible screen space.
- Zoom in and out using Cmd +/- (Mac) or Ctrl +/- (Windows)

Experiment with this provided code to see how the space can be manipulated to deal with larger programs.
markdown_instructions.PDK5 Challenges_markdown_instruction: What are your biggest challenges to implementing Code.org's curriculum in your classroom?

markdown_instructions.PDK5 Goals_markdown_instruction: What are your goals or intentions for integrating Code.org in your classroom?
markdown_instructions.PDK5 Impact 1_markdown_instruction: Do you think your students will find the online activities in the K-5 courses fun and engaging? Why or Why not?
markdown_instructions.PDK5 Impact 2_markdown_instruction: Does computer science connect to other topics or subjects your students are learning about? Explain why or why not.
markdown_instructions.PDK5 Impact 3_markdown_instruction: Does learning about computer science help students grow into the kind of citizens you are preparing them to be? Explain why or why not.
markdown_instructions.PDK5 Loops 2_markdown_instruction: In the last puzzle, you used a loop to get the bird to the pig with 2 blocks instead of using 5 "move forward" blocks. Why do you think it's important to write computer programs efficiently?

markdown_instructions.SG U3L02 Assessment_markdown_instruction:
This lesson introduced the notion of "efficiency" in programming, and that it might mean different things at different times.  Think of an example *outside* of computer science in which you have heard the term efficiency and compare it to the ways we talked about efficiency in programming.  

In what ways is the meaning of "efficiency" the same? In what ways is it different?
markdown_instructions.SG U3L02 Free Response Getting Started_m:
In this lesson we solved a series of problems with a limited set of commands (only 2). Give at least one reason why it's useful to learn how to solve and program solutions with a limited set of commands.

In this lesson we solved a series of problems using the `Move turtle` and `Orient turtle` subgoals. Give at least one reason that breaking problems down into subgoals is a good approach to solving problems.
markdown_instructions.SG U3L02 Free Response Wrap Up_markdown_:

* Were you able to be creative with such a limited set of tools?
* What was most frustrating about this activity? If you could add one additional block, what would it be and why? What subgoal would that block achieve?
markdown_instructions.SG U3L03 - draw rect function_markdown_i:
This is your code from the previous level.  Did you know that you can write functions that call your other functions?

Take the code that draws the rectangle and move it into a new function called `drawRectangle()`. The first line of your program should be a single call to `drawRectangle()`. The rest of the code should just be function definitions, including your definition for **right**.

You'll only need one subgoal for this, `//Define function`.

NOTE: your program will still do the same thing.  We are just changing the way it is written to demonstrate that you can use functions you've already written as building blocks in new functions.

![](https://images.code.org/fd6e8b4d2218a242bae19ac9c78b5d5f-image-1447799438050.gif)
markdown_instructions.SG U3L03 Free Response Wrap Up_markdown_: In your own words, explain at least one reason why programming languages have functions.  Include an example of something you did in this lesson that demonstrates the reason you describe.
markdown_instructions.SG U3L04 Assessment1_markdown_instructio:
Consider the figure below.  Use top-down thinking to design a solution to the problem.  In the space provided write a list of **just the names** of the functions that you would write in a program that draws this figure.  (Assume that the long line segments are 6 turtle moves long).

![](https://images.code.org/43895f8ceccb12f72e7f5ba03152a6e6-image-1441914144956.png)
markdown_instructions.SG U3L04 Free Response Wrap Up_markdown_: In the Create Performance Task, you will be asked to identify an abstraction in your program and explain how it helps manage the complexity of the program. Functions are a form of abstraction. Pick a function you wrote in your solution to the 3x3 square problem and explain how it helps manage the complexity of your program.
markdown_instructions.SG U3L06 Assessment_markdown_instruction: It is said that *functions with parameters generalize the behavior of a more specific command and allow programmers to use functions instead of duplicated code.* Explain what this means to you using the difference between turnLeft() and turnLeft(angle) as an example.
markdown_instructions.SG U3L07 Free Response Reflection_markdo:
When breaking a problem down, you often encounter elements that you want to use repeatedly in your code. Sometimes it's appropriate to write a new function; at other times it's appropriate to write a loop.  

There is no hard-and-fast rule as to which is better, but what do you think?  What kinds of circumstances would lead you to writing a function versus using a loop?
markdown_instructions.SG U3L08 Assessment2_markdown_instructio:
Abstraction is often used to focus on a general case and ignore a specific instance of a problem. 

Given this meaning of the word, how are functions with parameters an example of abstraction?

markdown_instructions.U1L1 - FR computer science word associat:
**Directions:**

You're in a class called *Computer Science Principles*.

You might not know anything about computer science right now.  You might know a few things.  We're going to take the pulse of the class to see on the first day what we think computer science involves, and we'll revisit this occasionally.

**Do this:**

In the text box below, answer the following two questions:

1. What is the compression rate? The compression rate says by how much the text was compressed from the original as a percentage. Don't forget that the compressed version of the text is the compressed text size + dictionary size. (see note below) 

2. Is this a "good" compression rate? Why or why not? 


(*NOTE: to calculate, the compression rate is slightly different than simply stating the compressed size as a fraction of the original. It's just opposite sides of the same coin. markdown_instructions.U3L03 - draw rect function_markdown_inst:
This is your code from the previous level.  Did you know that you can write functions that call your own functions?

Take the code that draws the rectangle and move into a new function called `drawRectangle()`. The first line of your program should be a single call to `drawRectangle()`. The rest of the code should just be function definitions. 

NOTE: your program will still do the same thing.  We are just changing the way it is written to demonstrate that you can use functions you've already written as building blocks in new functions.

markdown_instructions.U4L3 - FR Identifying people_2018_markdo:
Consider the following scenario:

*In order to dampen the effect of a potential data breach or accidental release of records a health care company has decided to remove a lot of personally identifiable information in its health records, like names, phone numbers and so on.  In its place, along with all medical information, they plan to store ONLY the gender, age, and zip code of the patient.*

**Give your opinion**: Is this health care company doing enough to protect the personal information of patients? If yes, explain why this is the best they can do. If no, explain what they should do instead.  (Limit your response to a few sentences).

markdown_instructions.Using Accelerometer Events_markdown_inst:
Today youre going to learn how to use and create **functions**.

Creating a function lets you make your own blocks! There are two parts to a function: 

Making a newly named block that has all of the code you want to run inside of it. 
-xml of function definition- 

The single green block itself that you use, or call, to run the function you created.
-xml of function call-

Prepare to get familiar with functions, learn how to edit them, and create your own!

Kiki the Soccer Girl wants to make sure her friends are loved on Valentine's Day! Program Kiki (Actor 1) to move left and right when the left and right arrows are pressed. When Kiki is clicked, she should throw hearts towards her friends. 

---
Click "Run" and play the game to find out how many friends she has to send love to in order to win!

markdown_instructions.Web Lab 1_markdown_instruction:
Make an awesome web page!

1. Look at the web page we gave you to start with. Look how lame it is. 1996 just called and wants its web page back. But don't get depressed - YOU can fix it!
2. Add a background-color attribute in the body style in style.css to make the page background color 'darkcyan'
3. Add a text-align attribute to the body style in style.css to center the image and text horizontally
4. Change index.html to include an inspiring hashtag
5. Add a color attribute to the p style in style.css to make the inspiring hashtag white
6. Add a font-size attribute to the p style in style.css to make your inspiring hashtag REALLY BIG! (Try 24px and 3em and see what happens.)

markdown_instructions.course3_playLab_challenge1_markdown_inst:
_The **squirrels** are terrified to see that a **dinosaur** has come to town! Can the brave **knight** keep them all from panicking?_

Rules:
1. *Touching the squirrels scores you points.*
2. *Touching the dinosaur takes many points away.*

Here is a different kind of game that has already been started for you! Play it to see how it works. 


Something should happen when you get enough points or when you run out of points. Add some code to the `win game` and `lose game` functions to make the game work the way it should. 
Click the hints for ideas!
markdown_instructions.course3_playlab_challenge2_markdown_inst:
Can you figure out how this "Fortune Teller" app works? Try adding some of the following features to this game:

* Change the "yes" and "no" answers to something more interesting.
* Let the player ask another question after the actor says the fortune.
* Give the witch two more things to say when she is in an `angry` or `normal` mood.
* Give the wizard his own set of fortunes.
* Make each actor change mood randomly.

Check the hints if you need help with these challenges!

![](https://images.code.org/109aa2afaa3b7b1ecebff518bacdf3c5-image-1500660008987.png) _Hi, Im Elsa of Arendelle, help me draw a shape._

Draw a small shape, between **20 and 50** pixels wide.  It can be any shape that you like.  
<hr/>

You can try making a polygon, like one of these:  
![](https://images.code.org/14e58b3901ca7c13319cc64f18ae5d82-image-1495765942356.21.06.png)
![](https://images.code.org/8f79d689ea4936a3725a37025f8fda40-image-1495765942357.25.49.png)

Or even an abstract shape, like one of these:  
![](https://images.code.org/8471c095219da3044b3830bebeedefb3-image-1496436883704.32.19.png)
![](https://images.code.org/2fe6ed2db5308f4b34f7632fc6b8a64d-image-1496436883705.40.32.png)
![](https://images.code.org/abb0947f634bc4b712d47516587a6cb8-image-1496436883705.47.21.png)
markdown_instructions.courseD_Frozen_nested2_markdown_instruct:
![](https://images.code.org/109aa2afaa3b7b1ecebff518bacdf3c5-image-1500660008987.png) _Now, lets draw more than one._ Now take your shape and draw two or three in a row by jumping forward some number of pixels. - If you jump forward by **less** than the width of your shape, they might overlap - If you jump forward by **more** than the width of your shape, you will get a gap
Your row might end up straight like with these: ![](https://images.code.org/cefc818d8636c7ce185738311870ff1d-image-1495820778762.39.25.png) ![](https://images.code.org/80dc77914de15685dc696825dff61723-image-1495820778762.39.43.png) ![](https://images.code.org/00cda078f119b1ddb0af27ae4a44b089-image-1495820778761.39.08.png)

Or, your shapes might move around like one of these: ![](https://images.code.org/0c4066fe7547bc1f4495aacbeecdea6d-image-1496437220447.47.04.png) ![](https://images.code.org/4069376b784c147a8d443d49e22f783f-image-1496437220446.40.15.png) ![](https://images.code.org/02704ab3fb3356f76c544bb64c1a7cce-image-1496437220446.32.04.png)

![](https://images.code.org/109aa2afaa3b7b1ecebff518bacdf3c5-image-1500660008987.png) _"What happens if we draw snowflakes on top of each other?"_

Try layering two different shapes of snowflakes on top of one another with a little turn in between - see what you get!
markdown_instructions.courseD_Frozen_nested5_markdown_instruct: ![](https://images.code.org/109aa2afaa3b7b1ecebff518bacdf3c5-image-1500660008987.png) _"Get creative with shapes and angles to see what kind of new snowflakes we can draw!"_
markdown_instructions.courseD_Frozen_nested7_markdown_instruct:
![](https://images.code.org/109aa2afaa3b7b1ecebff518bacdf3c5-image-1500660008987.png) _"Now lets turn and go back the way we came."_

Turn around 180 degrees and draw the exact same stair pattern again!  

- The rest of this stage will be easier if you put all of your code inside of a loop to make Elsa  draw, turn around 180 degrees, draw, then turn around 180 degrees again.

<hr/>

Here is an example of stairs that use a 76 degree turn:

![](https://images.code.org/ceea66fad37e79cc45a850911f90440c-image-1496696286635.16.27.png)
markdown_instructions.courseD_Frozen_nested9_markdown_instruct:
![](https://images.code.org/109aa2afaa3b7b1ecebff518bacdf3c5-image-1500660008987.png)  _"Now, what should we do? Lets explore and create our own winter wonderland!"_

Try playing around with what you've created. Draw whatever you like!
- What happens if you use two different angles in your stair step pattern?
- What happens if you make your diamond pattern longer or shorter?
- What does it look like to draw two snowflakes on top of one another?
markdown_instructions.courseD_artist_1_2018_markdown_instructi:
![](https://images.code.org/109aa2afaa3b7b1ecebff518bacdf3c5-image-1500660008987.png) _Hi, Im Elsa of Arendelle, help me draw a shape._

Draw a hexagon with 50 pixel long sides.  

---

To draw a hexagon, you will need to: 
- move forward by **50** pixels
- turn right by **60** degrees
- repeat a total of **6** times
markdown_instructions.courseD_artist_2_2018_markdown_instructi:
![](https://images.code.org/109aa2afaa3b7b1ecebff518bacdf3c5-image-1500660008987.png) _Good job!_

After your hexagon, turn right by **60** degrees, then draw a line that is **150** pixels long.   

Finish by putting Elsa back to the center of the play area, using the <xml><block type="jump_to"><title name="VALUE">middle center</title></block></xml> block.
markdown_instructions.courseD_artist_3_2018_markdown_instructi:

To turn this code into a snowflake, nest all of the code inside of another `repeat` loop and run it a total of **6** times.  You should only need to add one block.

**Inspiration:** Where do you need to add code if you want to draw a tiny square at the tip of each long line?

---
You can try whatever you want in this puzzle, but here is an idea:

Try making a tiny square at the end of each line
- Each side should be 15 pixels long
- You should turn by 90 degrees
- Repeat those actions a total of 4 times

___

![](https://images.code.org/ceea66fad37e79cc45a850911f90440c-image-1496696286635.16.27.png)
markdown_instructions.courseD_artist_project2a_2018_markdown_i:
![](https://images.code.org/109aa2afaa3b7b1ecebff518bacdf3c5-image-1500660008987.png) _"Now lets turn and go back the way we came."_

Turn around 180 degrees and draw the exact same stair pattern again!  

- The rest of this stage will be easier if you put all of your code inside of a loop to make Elsa  draw, turn around 180 degrees, draw, then turn around 180 degrees again.

<hr/>

Here is an example of stairs that use a 76 degree turn:

![](https://images.code.org/ceea66fad37e79cc45a850911f90440c-image-1496696286635.16.27.png)

Try layering two different shapes of snowflakes on top of one another with a little turn in between - see what you get!

markdown_instructions.courseD_bee_conditionals2_markdown_instr:
More clouds! 

Check underneath every cloud to see if it is hiding a flower before you get nectar. If there is a flower underneath the cloud, the bee will need to get nectar *once*.  

Remember: Not all clouds hide the same thing!
markdown_instructions.courseD_bee_conditionals2_2018_markdown_:
More clouds! 

Check underneath every cloud to see if it is hiding a flower before you get nectar. If there is a flower underneath the cloud, the bee will need to get nectar *once*.

markdown_instructions.courseD_bee_conditionals3_markdown_instr: You can only collect nectar from flowers, but you can check any space to see if there is a flower. If there is a flower under any of these clouds, the bee will need to collect nectar *once*.
markdown_instructions.courseD_bee_conditionals3_2018_markdown_: You can only collect nectar from flowers, but you can check any space to see if there is a flower. If there is a flower under any of these clouds, the bee will need to collect nectar *once*.

In this puzzle, we know that every flower has exactly one nectar, but the flowers aren't spaced evenly.

Get all of the nectar using as few blocks as possible.
markdown_instructions.courseD_bee_conditionals4_2018_markdown_:

markdown_instructions.courseD_bee_conditionals6_markdown_instr:
*"Now I just want to make honey."*

Some of these clouds might have honeycombs under them.  Be sure to check if a honeycomb is hiding behind each cloud! If there is a honeycomb, the bee will only need to make honey *once*.
markdown_instructions.courseD_bee_conditionals6_2018_markdown_:
*"Now I just want to make honey."*

markdown_instructions.courseD_bee_conditionals7_markdown_instr:
Sometimes a cloud covers a flower, sometimes it covers a honeycomb! 

Use the `if/else` block to collect nectar at flowers and make honey at honeycomb. Remember: if there is a flower, the bee only needs to get nectar *once*. If there is a honeycomb, the bee only needs to make honey *once*.

markdown_instructions.courseD_playLab_cond3a_markdown_instruct:

Add code so that when Pegleg gets to the dragon, he gets two points *if* the dragon is happy. Otherwise, he should get only one point added to his score.
markdown_instructions.courseD_playLab_cond3a_2018_markdown_ins:
It's time to use what we've learned about conditionals to make this game amazing.

markdown_instructions.courseD_playLab_cond3b_markdown_instruct: Use a `repeat forever` loop to make the dragon (actor 2) move up and down forever! Add a `wait for 1 second` block in between the `move up` and `move down` blocks for the dragon.
markdown_instructions.courseD_playLab_cond4_markdown_instructi:

markdown_instructions.courseD_playLab_cond5_markdown_instructi:

markdown_instructions.courseD_playLab_condFP_2018_markdown_ins:
Now, build your own game to show off to your friends!

---

You could:
  - Have the pirate and ninja work together to get points from the octopus
  - Have both octopuses follow the pirate, doing double damage to the ninja when they collide
  - Have each character disappear when touched by the ninja
  - Invent your own game!

markdown_instructions.courseE_artist_functions7_markdown_instr:
Let's take the code for the window and add it to function `draw a window`. Now, we can call the function any time we need to draw a window without having to write the code again. 

![](https://images.code.org/615a5e93abdaffeed438a976a56fc1f5-image-1497998528859.gif)

Try solving this puzzle by creating `draw a window` and calling it five times. Watch out for the door!

- The top windows are 50 pixels away from each other.  
- The bottom windows are 100 pixels below the top set.
markdown_instructions.courseE_artist_functions7_2018_markdown_:
Drawing all of these windows individually would be a pain!  

Try solving this puzzle by creating `draw a window` and calling it five times. Watch out for the door!

---  
- Each window is made up of four **25** pixel squares.
- The top windows are a **100** pixel jump away from each other.  
- The bottom windows are a **150** pixel jump below the top set.
markdown_instructions.courseE_artist_functions8_markdown_instr:
**Challenge:** Did you know that you can call functions from *inside* other functions?!

Create as many functions as you think you need to make this drawing of 50 pixel squares.
markdown_instructions.courseE_artist_functions8a_2018_markdown:

markdown_instructions.courseE_playLab_challenge1_markdown_inst:
_The **squirrels** are terrified to see that a **dinosaur** has come to town! Can the brave **knight** keep them all from panicking?_

Rules:
1. *Touching the squirrels scores you points.*
2. *Touching the dinosaur takes many points away.*

Here is a different kind of game that has already been started for you! Play it to see how it works. 


Something should happen when you get enough points or when you run out of points. Add some code to the `win game` and `lose game` functions to make the game work the way it should. 
Click the hints for ideas!

markdown_instructions.courseE_playlab_challenge2_markdown_inst:
Can you figure out how this "Fortune Teller" app works? Try adding some of the following features to this game:

* Change the "yes" and "no" answers to something more interesting.
* Let the player ask another question after the actor says the fortune.
* Give the witch two more things to say when she is in an `angry` or `normal` mood.
* Give the wizard his own set of fortunes.
* Make each actor change mood randomly.

Check the hints if you need help with these challenges!

markdown_instructions.courseF_IceAge_2_markdown_instruction: Manny (actor 2) found Sid (actor 1) and wants to invite him on an adventure. Help them greet each other by using the the `actor ___ say` block twice.
markdown_instructions.courseF_IceAge_3_markdown_instruction: Scrat is looking for his acorn! Can you help him move the last 200 pixels?
markdown_instructions.courseF_IceAge_4_markdown_instruction: Diego (actor 1) is searching for Manny (actor 2). Can you help bring the two together? Connect a block to the `when actor touches` event to play a sound when they find each other.
markdown_instructions.courseF_IceAge_5_markdown_instruction: The `repeat forever` block allows you to run code continuously. Can you put blocks inside of it to help Granny get some exercise by moving left and right repeatedly?
markdown_instructions.courseF_IceAge_6_markdown_instruction:
Can you help Sid call for his friends when you click on him?  

Once you're done, press "Run" to play.  Click on Sid to see your code work!
markdown_instructions.courseF_IceAge_7_markdown_instruction:
Scrat is still looking for acorns! 
Help him scamper around by attaching a `move actor 1` block to each of the events and changing the direction to work for each arrow key. 
When youre done, click "Run" and try to collect all of the acorns.
markdown_instructions.courseF_IceAge_8_markdown_instruction:
Here is your code from the last puzzle, as well as the code to move Granny left and right. 
Can you finish the program to make it so that you both **play a sound** and **score a point** when Sid and Granny collide? 
Press "Run" to play the game.
markdown_instructions.courseF_IceAge_9_markdown_instruction:
Everyone needs to move faster because an ice storm is coming! 
Change the scene to an icy background and set Sids (actor 1) speed to fast.
Press "Run" and move Sid to Diego to warn him.

markdown_instructions.courseF_artist_variables8_markdown_instr:
Rebuild the triangle code from the last puzzle, but this time use the `set length to` block to reset the `length` variable to `length`+10 at the end of each loop iteration.

<xml>
<block type="variables_set" inline="false">
                        <title name="VAR">length</title>
                        <value name="VALUE">
                          <block type="math_arithmetic" inline="true">
                            <title name="OP">ADD</title>
                            <value name="A">
                              <block type="variables_get">
                                <title name="VAR">length</title>
                              </block>
                            </value>
                            <value name="B">
                              <block type="math_number">
                                <title name="NUM">10</title>
                              </block>
                            </value>
                          </block>
                        </value>
                      </block>
</xml>

The length of the first side of the triangle is 150 pixels.

                            <value name="A">
                              <block type="variables_get">
                                <title name="VAR">length</title>
                              </block>

</xml>

markdown_instructions.courseF_bee_conditionals10_markdown_inst:
Conditionals can be helpful, even when you know exactly what is in each spot!

Collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey.
markdown_instructions.courseF_bee_conditionals10_2018_markdown:
Conditionals can be helpful, even when you know exactly what is in each spot!

Collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey.
markdown_instructions.courseF_bee_conditionals1_predict1_markd:
*"This cloud is blocking my view!"*

Check to see if there's a flower under the cloud. If there's a flower, get nectar.
markdown_instructions.courseF_bee_conditionals1_predict1_2018_:
*"This cloud is blocking my view!"*

Check to see if there's a flower under the cloud. If there's a flower, get nectar.
markdown_instructions.courseF_bee_conditionals2_markdown_instr:
*"It's too cloudy to see any flowers!"*

Check underneath every cloud to see if it is hiding a flower before you get nectar. If there is a flower underneath the cloud, the bee will need to get nectar **once**.  

Remember: Not all clouds hide the same thing!
markdown_instructions.courseF_bee_conditionals2_2018_markdown_:
*"It's too cloudy to see any flowers!"*

Check underneath every cloud to see if it is hiding a flower before you get nectar. If there is a flower underneath the cloud, the bee will need to get nectar **once**.  

Remember: Not all clouds hide the same thing!
markdown_instructions.courseF_bee_conditionals3_markdown_instr: You can only collect nectar from flowers, but you can check any space to see if there is a flower. If there is a flower under any of these clouds, the bee will need to collect nectar **once**.
markdown_instructions.courseF_bee_conditionals3_2018_markdown_: You can only collect nectar from flowers, but you can check any space to see if there is a flower. If there is a flower under any of these clouds, the bee will need to collect nectar **once**.
markdown_instructions.courseF_bee_conditionals4_markdown_instr:

Get all of the nectar using as few blocks as possible.

Use the `if/else` block to collect nectar at flowers and make honey at honeycomb.

Collect nectar once if there is a flower. Otherwise, make honey once (because there is a honeycomb).

Try collecting these flowers using an **increment** of 2.

markdown_instructions.courseF_bee_functions2_markdown_instruct:
To make things easier, it's time to learn about functions!

From here on out, you will be using a new *function editor*.  This editor is a separate window that will appear when you go to edit a function.  You won't see all of the code from your function while you're coding in the workspace, but don't worry...it's still there!  
___

Let's practice with this function that gets nectar only if the bee is at a flower.  To see the code inside, click the blue "edit" button!

Use the `get only nectar` function to collect the nectar from each flower.

* Give the witch two more things to say when she is in an `angry` or `normal` mood.
* Give the wizard his own set of fortunes.
* Make each actor change mood randomly.

Check the hints if you need help with these challenges!

_NOTE: Use a new line for each entry to the table. Write each line in the format of "Function Name : Description"_

**Top-Down Design Strategy:**

* Look at the big picture
* Identify a sub-task
* Break down that sub-task into smaller sub-task(s)...
* Keep going until youre down to the commands you already have access to.

|-----------------|-----------------------------|

markdown_instructions.cspu5_assess2_match_markdown_instruction:
The following statements are true about event handlers, if-statements, or both in App Lab.  Place the letter next to each statement into the appropriate area of the table below.

**Statements:**

* A. Runs code in response to a user action
* B. Runs code in response to statement being evaluated to True
* C. Evaluated sequentially once execution is inside the statement
* D. Can be triggered at any time
* E. Used to run a block of code

_Note: Make a new line for each box._

    Event Handlers: x, x
    if Statements: x, x
    Both: x, x

markdown_instructions.cspu5_assess2_trueFalse_markdown_instruc:
For each expression below, circle whether it evaluates to true or false. The variable temperature is initialized as shown.

    var temperature = 30;

Expressions:

* (temperature > 0) && (temperature < 32)
* (temperature > 0) || (temperature < 32)
* (temperature != 0) && (temperature < 32)
* (temperature == 0) || (temperature > 32)
* (temperature < 0) || (temperature > 32)

_Note: Write "true" or "false" on a new line for each expression._

markdown_instructions.frozen circle function in circle_markdow: Now let's create 20 overlapping circles, turning 18 degrees between each circle.
markdown_instructions.frozen circle function with parameter_ma: Here's a Create circle block that can make circles of different sizes. Can you use this to create a small circle of size 5 and a larger circle of size 10?
markdown_instructions.frozen circle function_markdown_instruct: Use the new Create a circle block to create 10 overlapping circles. Don't forget to jump forward between circles.
markdown_instructions.frozen circle_markdown_instruction: A circle is a special shape. Can you figure out what number to replace the question marks with to draw a circle?
markdown_instructions.frozen cross rotate dense_markdown_instr: Let's repeat it 90 times! How many times does 90 go into 360? Hint: It's a really small number.
markdown_instructions.frozen cross rotate_markdown_instruction: Now try repeating it 10 times. How many degrees do you need to turn between each line?
markdown_instructions.frozen cross_markdown_instruction: Wrap a Repeat block around these commands to create a plus sign. Did you notice Elsa can move forward and backward?
markdown_instructions.frozen diamond mini snowflake_markdown_i: Did you know every snowflake is a different shape? Let's create a new snowflake by using another Repeat" block to repeat a parallelogram 4 times, turning right by 90 degrees between each parallelogram.
markdown_instructions.frozen diamond snowflake_markdown_instru: Now, let's create a new snowflake by using the repeat block to repeat a parallelogram 10 times, turning right by 36 degrees between each one.
markdown_instructions.frozen diamond_markdown_instruction: Use a repeat around these blocks to create a parallelogram. It's just like a rectangle but has different angles. This one has 60 degree and 120 degree angles instead of all 90 degree angles.
markdown_instructions.frozen freeplay_markdown_instruction: You've officially become a master artist! Create a winter wonderland.
markdown_instructions.frozen perpendicular_markdown_instructio: Now let's see if we can create two lines that are at a 90 degree angle to each other. You will need to use the "Turn" block as well as the "Move" block.
markdown_instructions.frozen snowflake branch_markdown_instruc: Try using the Create a snowflake branch block to create three branches, which starts to look like a snowflake.
markdown_instructions.frozen snowflake full_markdown_instructi: Now let's repeat it 8 times to make a beautiful snowflake!
markdown_instructions.frozen snowflower_markdown_instruction: Intricate snow patterns can be created with very simple shapes. Can you make a pattern by repeating 5 circles of size 5 and 5 circles of size 10?
markdown_instructions.frozen square iterative_markdown_instruc: It seems like we're halfway to making a square. Let's put 4 lines together to create a square.
markdown_instructions.frozen square loop 3x_markdown_instructi: Let's create three squares, turning after each square. Be sure to turn by 120 degrees before each new square.
markdown_instructions.frozen square loop_markdown_instruction: Hi, Im Anna of Arendelle! Lets make a square with the Repeat block, which uses fewer blocks. How many times (???) should the Repeat block loop the blocks inside it to make a square?
markdown_instructions.frozen square snowflake_markdown_instruc: Can you create a snowflake using the Repeat block to make a square 10 times, and the Turn block to turn 36 degrees between each square?

Use your imagination. What can you do to make this game more fun?
Need some ideas?
  • Conversation - Add blocks so that the characters say "Hello!" when they run into each other.
  • Where's the Dragon? - Have the dragon dissapear when the up arrow key is pressed.
  • Super Dragon - Make the dragon move at a faster speed and then try to catch him with the knight.

*"Let's make a cage for my pet monster!"*

Drag blocks onto the screen to have the artist draw over the grey lines in the picture.  
(Each line is 100 pixels long)

*"This spaceship needs a window!"*

Each side of the inner square is 100 pixels and all of the angles are 90 degrees.
markdown_instructions.grade2_MakeDogTag_3_markdown_instruction:

Finish Starla's rocket so she can chase her pet.  
(Each side of the triangle is 100 pixels long and has 120 degree outer angles)
markdown_instructions.grade2_MakeDogTag_4_markdown_instruction:
*"Maybe we should make a tag for each of our pets in case they get lost!"*

Finish this tag by drawing a rectangle around the outside.  
(The long sides are 200 pixels each and the short sides are each 100 pixels)
markdown_instructions.grade2_MakeDogTag_5_markdown_instruction:
*"Now a tag for Belle!"*

Draw this diamond with 200 pixel sides.
markdown_instructions.grade2_MakeDogTag_6_markdown_instruction:

(The long side is 150 pixels and each of the short sides are 75 pixels.)
markdown_instructions.grade2_MakeDogTag_7_markdown_instruction:
One more tag.  This is a triangle for Pi.  
(Each side is 150 pixels)
markdown_instructions.grade2_MakeDogTag_8_markdown_instruction: Now let's connect a bunch of V's together in a loop.
markdown_instructions.grade2_MakeDogTag_9_markdown_instruction:

Rebuild the code from the last puzzle, but this time, add a left turn of 30 degrees inside the loop. Now, repeat it 24 times instead of 8.

markdown_instructions.grade3_ConditionalsElse_1_markdown_instr:
This cloud is blocking my view! 

Check to see if there's a flower under the cloud, and only get nectar if there's a flower.   
Be careful, it can change!
markdown_instructions.grade3_ConditionalsElse_2_markdown_instr:
More clouds! 

Check underneath every cloud to see if it is hiding a flower before you get nectar.  

Remember: Not all clouds hide the same thing!
markdown_instructions.grade3_ConditionalsElse_4_markdown_instr:
Sometimes this cloud covers a flower, and sometimes it covers a honeycomb! 

Use the `if/else` block to collect nectar only if it is a flower.  
Else, make honey (because it is a honeycomb).
markdown_instructions.grade3_ConditionalsElse_5_markdown_instr:
There will be either a flower or a honeycomb under each of those clouds!

Use the `if/else` block to collect nectar if there is a flower.

markdown_instructions.grade4_playlab_freeplay_markdown_instruc:
It's free play time! Have fun with all the blocks in your tool box.
Need some ideas?
  • Tag - Have character 2 patrol and use your arrow keys to make character 1 chase until they collide.
  • Whack-a-Sprite - Have a character constantly pop up at a random location. Award points for clicking the sprite before it disappears.
  • Best Guess - Make both characters disappear, change location to a random spot, then reappear as a random character. Click on the first one and get a point...but if you click on the second one you LOSE a point!

markdown_instructions.grade4_scaffolded_project1_markdown_inst:
It is amazing how much you have learned! Let's put them together to make a game, step by step.
To start, let's set up your game's space and actor. We've put these blocks in your tool box. Choose a background and map, and pick an actor to be your game's hero.

![](https://images.code.org/745931ce34b3c47de19c36009e4a9c48-image-1471464938470.14.47 PM.png)
markdown_instructions.grade4_scaffolded_project2_markdown_inst:
Now let's get things moving! Use event handlers and actions to make your hero move.

We've added these blocks to your tool box to help you.

![](https://images.code.org/6216c0559cfae16005ffb53e6532473b-image-1471472994205.23.54 PM.png)
markdown_instructions.grade4_scaffolded_project3_markdown_inst:
Now that your game has a hero, it's time to start adding other actors and assigning them behaviors. 

Add two or more additional actors to your game and make them move. Do you want to have an actor patrol back and forth? Try using a these new blocks to bring these other components of your game to life!

![](https://images.code.org/4cfffd476c6129891eb8bde246a711a8-image-1472065288448.00.42 PM.png)

**NOTE:** Chasing and fleeing behavior commands are coming soon!
markdown_instructions.grade4_scaffolded_project4_markdown_inst:
Just getting the actors moving is a great step, but we need to program some interactions to make this really feel like a game. A simple way to do this is to add or remove points when actors collide with projectiles or each other. Find some interesting ways to change the score in your game.

*Don't expect to get this right on the first try. Keep testing your game as you code. You'll not only want a game that works, but one that is fun to play!*

We've added these blocks to your toolbox:

![](https://images.code.org/ad0df96aa91c89e3d903dce2fe19517f-image-1472070105051.20.55 PM.png)

markdown_instructions.grade5_artist_binary1_markdown_instructi:
Binary is a way of representing information using only two options.  Here, we're going to use the options "off" (represented by the number 0) and "on" (represented by the number 1).   

We've provided you with a grid of "pixels" that you can walk through and make designs by turning on only certain squares.  

**Can you have the artist draw "01010101" in binary in the first row?**
markdown_instructions.grade5_artist_binary10_markdown_instruct: **Free-Play Inspiration:** You've now learned everything you need to know to make a pattern like this! If this picture inspires you, try to make something similar. Otherwise, create something all your own.
markdown_instructions.grade5_artist_binary2_markdown_instructi:
Here's a function that takes a binary string of 1's and 0's and instructs the artist to follow them from left to right, top to bottom.  

The artist will fill-in the squares when it sees a 1 and ignore the square when it sees a 0. 

**Run this code to see how the artist uses binary to draw this pattern.**
markdown_instructions.grade5_artist_for_loops1_markdown_instru: Use a `for` loop to draw this triangle that is 50 pixels wide. If you count from 1 to 3 by 1s, you can use this just like a `repeat` loop.
markdown_instructions.grade5_artist_for_loops10_markdown_instr: **Challenge:** Can you figure out how to use all of the things you've learned to create this image of polygons, all with 40 pixel sides?
markdown_instructions.grade5_artist_for_loops1a_markdown_instr: Try using a `for loop`to create this triangular design. Don't worry that the numbers are different than the last puzzle. As long as you turn by the right number of degrees, the artist will make the correct shape!
markdown_instructions.grade5_artist_for_loops1b_markdown_instr: **Free Play:** Experiment with the `for` loop and the `counter` variable. Drag out a few blocks and see what happens.
markdown_instructions.grade5_artist_for_loops2_markdown_instru: Use a `repeat` inside of a `for` loop to create this stack of triangles that goes from 50 pixels to 100 pixels.
markdown_instructions.grade5_artist_for_loops3_markdown_instru: These triangles go from 20 pixel sides to 200 pixel sides, and each triangle is 20 pixels larger than the last.
markdown_instructions.grade5_artist_for_loops4_markdown_instru: These squares start at 15 pixels long, the largest is 300 pixels long, and each square is 15 pixels larger than the last.
markdown_instructions.grade5_artist_for_loops5_markdown_instru:
Just one little change to the code from the last image can create this drawing. Can you figure out what that change is?

Hint:  You need to remove something!
markdown_instructions.grade5_artist_for_loops6_markdown_instru:
If you turn a little bit more or less than you normally would for a shape, it creates a neat effect.

Try using some of the code from the last level, but turning 89 degrees to create this twisted square spiral.

Make three small changes to the code from the last level to get this!  
(This time, the `for` loop increments by 2)
markdown_instructions.grade5_artist_for_loops7a_markdown_instr: Take the angle down to 72 degrees to get a spiraled pentagon.
markdown_instructions.grade5_artist_for_loops7b_markdown_instr:
Use the counter inside the `set alpha` block to get this faded center.  
(This hexagon pattern was made using a 60 degree turn.)
markdown_instructions.grade5_artist_for_loops8_markdown_instru:
Remember back in a previous stage when we used a variable to control the number of sides in a shape? We are going to do the same thing with the `counter` variable now.  

This pattern starts with a triangle and adds one side at a time until it draws a decagon (10 sides). Each side should be 100 pixels long. 

How will you use the `counter` variable from the `for` loop to recreate this drawing?
markdown_instructions.grade5_artist_for_loops9_markdown_instru:
Let's put it all together!   

Using your knowledge of `for` loops and the `counter` variable, create this drawing where each shape has two more sides than the last.  Make sure that each side is 10 times as long as the number of sides in the polygon.

Very little of the code has been provided for you.

markdown_instructions.grade5_artist_for_loopsfreeplay12_markdo: **Free Play:** Try using the `counter` variable with other drawing elements to make magical images like this one.

markdown_instructions.grade5_artist_variables_octagons13_markd:
When a shape has lots of sides, each side needs to be shorter if you want the whole pattern to fit on the screen. 

Let's recreate the algorithm for this amazing pattern, but instead of manually setting the `length` variable, let's use a math block with the `sides` variable inside to make sure that each shape fits correctly.  

The perimeter of each polygon is 300 pixels.
markdown_instructions.grade5_artist_variables_pentagon8_markdo:

markdown_instructions.grade5_artist_variables_rectangle6_markd: Now I want to make a rectangle that is twice as tall as it is wide. We've got a variable called `width` that needs to be set to 100. Can you use the math blocks to complete the code?

markdown_instructions.grade5_bee_for_loops10_markdown_instruct:
If your loop is counting down, the increment is **subtracted** from your counter variable each time through. 

What should your increment be to collect 15, then 12, then 9, 6, 3 nectar?
markdown_instructions.grade5_bee_for_loops11_markdown_instruct:
**Challenge:** Take what you've learned about `for` loops and try to solve this problem. 

Remember: You may have to run through solutions multiple times before you figure out all of the steps.
markdown_instructions.grade5_bee_for_loops2_markdown_instructi:
Add the code necessary to make sure the bee collects all the nectar.

Look at how much code you need for this puzzle! (We'll learn a simpler way in the next puzzle.)
markdown_instructions.grade5_bee_for_loops3_markdown_instructi:
Ah, the `for` loop makes this much easier!  

Try this puzzle using the `for` loop with `counter` variable and see how much shorter your code becomes.
markdown_instructions.grade5_bee_for_loops4_markdown_instructi: Help the bee collect all of the nectar.
markdown_instructions.grade5_bee_for_loops5_markdown_instructi: Now we need to `move forward` `counter` times, then `get nectar` `counter` times.  Can you use two `repeat` loops to solve this challenge?
markdown_instructions.grade5_bee_for_loops6_markdown_instructi: You can also use a `for loop` to count down. Try gathering this nectar by counting down from 5 to 1 by 1.
markdown_instructions.grade5_bee_for_loops7_markdown_instructi:
The last number in your `for` loop is called the **"increment"**.  Each time the loop is run, the counter variable changes by the value of the increment.

Try collecting these flowers using an increment of 2.
markdown_instructions.grade5_bee_for_loops8_markdown_instructi:
You've got this!  

What should your increment be to collect 3, 6, 9, 12, 15 nectar?
markdown_instructions.grade5_bee_for_loops9_markdown_instructi:
Now, let's combine the `counter` variable with a math block! 

How can you use the `counter` variable to navigate this garden with the fewest number of blocks possible?
markdown_instructions.grade5_bee_parameters_new1_markdown_inst: Check beneath the clouds to see if the flowers have any nectar.
markdown_instructions.grade5_bee_parameters_new3_markdown_inst:
Time to put the function to the test! 

Let's see if it makes collecting these three rows of nectar any easier.
markdown_instructions.grade5_bee_parameters_new4_markdown_inst:
*"How is your function holding up?"*   

We need to make some adjustments here. Click "edit" to add a `length` parameter to the function so that it will still work when the row is a different length.
markdown_instructions.grade5_bee_parameters_new5_markdown_inst:
*"You're doing great so far!"*

Let's use this function to collect a lot of nectar.

markdown_instructions.grade5_bee_parameters_new9a_markdown_ins: Use your new function to solve this spiral.
markdown_instructions.grade5_playlab_freeplay_markdown_instruc:
It's free play time! Have fun with all the blocks in your tool box.
Need some ideas?
  • Tag - Have character 2 patrol and use your arrow keys to make character 1 chase until they collide.
  • Whack-a-Sprite - Have a character constantly pop up at a random location. Award points for clicking the sprite before it disappears.
  • Best Guess - Make both characters disappear, change location to a random spot, then reappear as a random character. Click on the first one and get a point...but if you click on the second one you LOSE a point!
markdown_instructions.grade5_playlab_variables10_markdown_inst: Edit the the `patrol` function to add an `actor` parameter, so that we can call it for each of the actors on the screen. Remember, the actors correspond to numbers 1, 2, and 3.
markdown_instructions.grade5_playlab_variables11_markdown_inst: Add another parameter called `speed` to the `patrol` function. Try using a `set speed` block with the new `speed` parameter to help Penguin get both flags before the other sprites even get one.
markdown_instructions.grade5_playlab_variables12_markdown_inst:
Let's have some fun! Look at the code provided to see if you can figure out what each block does.  

When you're done, use the arrow keys to control Dog and collect all of the flags.

**NOTE:** You don't need to make any changes to the program
markdown_instructions.grade5_playlab_variables13_markdown_inst: Use the `when actor touches` block to send Dog back to the top-left ONLY if Dog touches any of the other actors.
markdown_instructions.grade5_playlab_variables14_markdown_inst:
It's free play time! Have fun with all the blocks in your tool box.
Need some ideas?
  • Tag - Have character 2 patrol and use your arrow keys to make character 1 chase until they collide.
  • Whack-a-Sprite - Have a character constantly pop up at a random location. Award points for clicking the sprite before it disappears.
  • Best Guess - Make both characters disappear, change location to a random spot, then reappear as a random character. Click on the first one and get a point...but if you click on the second one you LOSE a point!
markdown_instructions.grade5_playlab_variables1ask_markdown_in:
This time, when you press 'run', you will see a 'prompt' asking you for a number. This number will be stored in a variable used to set the dog's speed.


Pay attention to how this program is written!
markdown_instructions.grade5_playlab_variables2_markdown_instr: The race in that last puzzle wasn't very fair! Change the `dog_speed` variable to make sure you can collect more flags than Cat. The first to collect 10 flags wins!
markdown_instructions.grade5_playlab_variables3_markdown_instr:
Here's a new kind of game! 

You don't need to change anything on this level.

**Directions:** Use the left and right arrows to move, and the up arrow to jump. See if you can collect all of the flags.
markdown_instructions.grade5_playlab_variables4_markdown_instr: Now we're using a variable called `height` to control how high the dog can jump. Update the `height` variable so that the dog can jump high enough to reach all the flags.
markdown_instructions.grade5_playlab_variables6_markdown_instr:
In our game, how should we score points?

1. Add 1 to your `points` variable each time Dog hits Cat with a piece of pie.
2. Use the `when actor 2 touches anything` event to trigger an update to your score. You can increment your variable by setting `points = points + 1.`
3. Get your score up to 10 to pass the level.

**Note:** Use the right arrow to throw pie!
markdown_instructions.grade5_playlab_variables6ask_markdown_in:
This time, you need 100 points to win!  Don't worry though, you can choose how many points you earn each time you score a hit!
Try adding the `ask` block and changing the number 1 out for the variable `value`.

**Note:** Use the right arrow to throw pie!
markdown_instructions.grade5_playlab_variables7_markdown_instr:
Nice, now let's make sure this game isn't too easy to play!

Any time Dog (actor 1) gets hit by a sandwich from Cat (actor 2), you should lose a point.

Start with 10 points so it's not too hard. Let your score drop down from 10 to 0 to pass the level.
markdown_instructions.grade5_playlab_variables9_markdown_instr:
Here's a function called `patrol`. 

Edit `patrol` to move Cat up 400 pixels and then down 400 pixels.
markdown_instructions.grade5_playlab_variables_freeplay_markdo:
Free Play time! Here are all of the variables we've played with so far in this stage, as well as a few more in case you want them. 

Notice that there are now so many blocks in our toolbox that they need to be organized!  Here, we've put each piece into an appropriate category.  Take some time to explore everything that is available. When you're done browsing, make a game or story using repeats, variables, and events.  

*Hint: scroll down to see all the commands in the workspace.*
markdown_instructions.grade5_playlab_variables_jump1_markdown_: This puzzle uses a hidden function that makes the dog jump when the `up` arrow is pressed. The height of the jumps can be set at the start of the game using the `jumpPower` variable. Try to touch all of the flags!
markdown_instructions.grade5_prompt_test_markdown_instruction: Variables aren't always numbers. What if you wanted to store a word or text? Experiment with the new `ask` block.

markdown_instructions.iceage_hello1_markdown_instruction:
Sid (actor 1) wants to gather everyone for a new adventure. Can you help him say "Hello!" by dragging the `say` block out and connecting it to the bottom of the `when run` event?   

Don't forget to type "Hello!" inside!
markdown_instructions.iceage_hello1_2018_markdown_instruction:
Sid (actor 1) wants to gather everyone for a new adventure. Can you help him say "Hello!" by dragging the `say` block out and connecting it to the bottom of the `when run` event?   

Don't forget to type "Hello!" inside!
markdown_instructions.iceage_hello2_markdown_instruction: Manny (actor 2) found Sid (actor 1) and wants to invite him on an adventure. Help them greet each other by using the the `actor ___ say` block twice.
markdown_instructions.iceage_hello2_2018_markdown_instruction: Manny (actor 2) found Sid (actor 1) and wants to invite him on an adventure. Help them greet each other by using the the `actor ___ say` block twice.
markdown_instructions.iceage_move_events_markdown_instruction:
Scrat is still looking for acorns! 
Help him scamper around by attaching a `move actor 1` block to each of the events and changing the direction to work for each arrow key. 
When youre done, click "Run" and try to collect all of the acorns.

markdown_instructions.iceage_move_to_actor_markdown_instructio: Diego (actor 1) is searching for Manny (actor 2). Can you help bring the two together? Connect a block to the `when actor touches` event to play a sound when they find each other.

markdown_instructions.iceage_move_to_flag_markdown_instruction: Scrat is looking for his acorn! Can you help him move the last 200 pixels?
markdown_instructions.iceage_move_to_flag_2018_markdown_instru: Scrat is looking for his acorn! Can you help him move the last 200 pixels?
markdown_instructions.iceage_repeat_markdown_instruction: The `repeat forever` block allows you to run code continuously. Can you put blocks inside of it to help Granny get some exercise by moving left and right repeatedly?
markdown_instructions.iceage_repeat_2018_markdown_instruction: The `repeat forever` block allows you to run code continuously. Can you put blocks inside of it to help Granny get some exercise by moving left and right repeatedly?
markdown_instructions.iceage_sound_and_points_markdown_instruc:
Here is your code from the last puzzle, as well as the code to move Granny left and right. 
Can you finish the program to make it so that you both **play a sound** and **score a point** when Sid and Granny collide? 
Press "Run" to play the game.

markdown_instructions.iceage_throw_hearts_markdown_instruction:
Sid wants to let his grandmother, Granny, know that he loves her.   

Use the `actor __ throw` command to have Sid (actor 1) throw hearts at Granny (actor 2)! 
Set Granny's mood to happy when she gets hit with the hearts.
markdown_instructions.iceage_throw_hearts_2018_markdown_instru:

Set Granny's mood to happy when she gets hit with the hearts.
markdown_instructions.iceage_warn_ice_age_markdown_instruction:
Everyone needs to move faster because an ice storm is coming! 
Change the scene to an icy background and set Sids (actor 1) speed to fast.
Press "Run" and move Sid to Diego to warn him.
markdown_instructions.iceage_warn_ice_age_2018_markdown_instru:

markdown_instructions.kikiTesta_markdown_instruction:
Our adventurer wants to collect coins.  But she can only use 4 blocks to get them.  

Can you help her grab as many as she can using just 4 blocks?
markdown_instructions.level 'grade3_Loops_10_markdown_instruct:
Such a busy bee!

Help Bee collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey with the fewest blocks possible.
markdown_instructions.level 'grade3_Loops_11_markdown_instruct:
The shape of this path is different from the others. 

Can you collect all of the nectar using as few blocks as possible?
markdown_instructions.level 'grade3_Loops_3_markdown_instructi: Use a `repeat` loop to collect all of the nectar.
markdown_instructions.level 'grade3_Loops_4_markdown_instructi: Now use the `repeat` block to collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey.
markdown_instructions.level 'grade3_Loops_5_markdown_instructi:
What a beautiful field of flowers!   

Help the bee visit each one.

Can you find a way to do it with fewer than 7 blocks?
markdown_instructions.level 'grade3_Loops_6_markdown_instructi:
How many times can loops help you in this puzzle?  

Loops are your friend! Use a few of them to complete this puzzle with the fewest blocks possible.
markdown_instructions.level 'grade3_Loops_7_markdown_instructi:
Those flowers look tasty!

Collect nectar from each of the flowers using the fewest blocks possible.
markdown_instructions.loop pet test 2_markdown_instruction:
**CHALLENGE!** When Daisy gets a carrot, she gets excited. Can you make Daisy start doing a dance party? She should never stop, even after you take the carrot away.

You will have to use all these blocks:
![](https://images.code.org/83c295bd00536dffed3c93a40bba75ae-image-1523562330282.41.06 PM.png)
markdown_instructions.loop pet test 3_markdown_instruction:
**Make Predictions!** Write down your answers to these questions before clicking "Run". Then try the code and see what happens!

* What will Daisy the dog do after you drag the carrot to her?
* What will Daisy the dog do after you press the Up arrow key?
markdown_instructions.loop pet test 4_markdown_instruction:
**It's time to make your own virtual pet!** You can change whatever code you want to to make your own pet. Here are some ideas:

* Can you make your pet start something new when you click on it?
* Can you make your pet run away when you drag the vacuum to it?
* Can you add other animal friends to your pet's area?
markdown_instructions.love_spring_1_markdown_instruction:
Let's celebrate Spring!  

We have put some seeds in the ground to prepare for the season's flowers.  Can you cover them up so that the birds don't eat them?
markdown_instructions.love_spring_2_markdown_instruction:
Our flowers are in full bloom!  

Now we need the bee to grab nectar from each one so he can make plenty of honey back at his hive!
markdown_instructions.playEventsK1_markdown_instruction:
This game is called "Play Lab".

See if you can figure out what each block does.
markdown_instructions.playEventsK2_markdown_instruction:
Jorge wants to say "Hi there."

Can you help?

![](https://images.code.org/f32d285fa6f45e1f8d042c04c55f32c8-image-1467988839292.gif)
markdown_instructions.playEventsK3_markdown_instruction:
Jorge wants to be scratched behind the ears!

Can you make it so that when you click Jorge he is happy?

![](https://images.code.org/04fb37990455b215e0f20884363092d0-image-1467988943134.gif)
markdown_instructions.playEventsK4_markdown_instruction:
Can you make it so that Jorge the dog chases Robin the bird when you click the up arrow?

![](https://images.code.org/2fbf6c793bb77a961fa7a52f27e4c59d-image-1467989013878.gif)
markdown_instructions.playEventsK5_markdown_instruction:
Now add code so that Robin flies away when you click the forward arrow.

![](https://images.code.org/a7e224c5f13e39e5342011f8a76d3b6b-image-1467989101328.gif)
markdown_instructions.playEventsK6_markdown_instruction:
Have Robin talk back to Jorge when you click on her.

![](https://images.code.org/fc80b1febbb7a472026b6bf2c535b2f4-image-1467989171517.gif)
markdown_instructions.playEventsK7_markdown_instruction:
What else can you do in this fun scene?
Need some ideas?
  • Conversation - Have the sprites talk to eachother when you click on them.
  • Pinball - Make one sprite play a noise when the other runs into it.
  • Arrows - Write a program so when each arrow key is pressed, the sprite moves in that direction!

markdown_instructions.test peer review_markdown_instruction: At this point you've seen 7 of the 14 lessons from unit 1. Thinking about those lessons, and looking across the other lessons in unit 1 work with your partner to develop a set of recommendations for using group work and peer learning in Unit 1. Your recommendations should include: - Which lessons or activities provide opportunities for group work and peer learning? - What recommendations do you have for using group work and peer learning in Unit 1 lessons? Use the space below to record any recommendations or commentary you have for others. Once you submit, another participant will review chance to send you feedback!
